column2: Most severe form of holoprosencephaly with single monoventricle, no separation of cerebral hemispheres, cyclopia or severe facial anomalies; "complete failure of brain division, single eye, proboscis"
column3: Most severe form of holoprosencephaly with complete failure of prosencephalon division; single monoventricle with no interhemispheric fissure; often associated with trisomy 13 or other chromosomal abnormalities
column4: Subset of holoprosencephaly cases; most severe form; frequently results in fetal demise or early neonatal death
column5: Single monoventricle, cyclopia (single eye or partially divided eye in single orbit), proboscis above eye, ethmocephaly (closely spaced eyes with proboscis between), cebocephaly (closely spaced eyes with single-nostril nose), premaxillary agenesis with median cleft lip
column6: Detectable on first-trimester ultrasound; most cases lethal in utero or shortly after birth; rare survivors have profound neurological impairment
column7: Semilobar holoprosencephaly, lobar holoprosencephaly, other severe brain malformations, anencephaly
column8: Prenatal ultrasound showing single ventricle detectable in first trimester; fetal MRI confirming monoventricle and absent interhemispheric structures; karyotype (trisomy 13 in 40 to 60%); genetic testing
column9: Supportive care only; most cases incompatible with life; palliative care discussions; genetic counseling regarding recurrence risk and chromosomal abnormalities

column2: Elderly patient with progressive memory loss, difficulty with word-finding, getting lost in familiar places, and inability to manage finances; "memory loss plus functional decline"
column3: Progressive accumulation of extracellular amyloid-beta plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein; leads to synaptic dysfunction, neuronal loss, and brain atrophy, particularly in hippocampus and temporal-parietal cortex
column4: Most common cause of dementia; affects over 58 million people worldwide; prevalence increases with age (doubles every 5 years after age 65); apolipoprotein E epsilon 4 allele is major genetic risk factor
column5: Early: short-term memory loss, word-finding difficulty, misplacing items; Middle: disorientation, impaired judgment, behavioral changes, apraxia, agnosia; Late: loss of speech, inability to recognize family, incontinence, complete dependence for activities of daily living
column6: Insidious onset; progressive decline over years (average 8 to 10 years from diagnosis to death); progresses through mild cognitive impairment, mild dementia, moderate dementia, to severe dementia
column7: Vascular dementia, Lewy body dementia, frontotemporal dementia, normal pressure hydrocephalus, depression (pseudodementia), vitamin B12 deficiency, hypothyroidism, medication effects
column8: Clinical diagnosis using National Institute on Aging-Alzheimer Association criteria; cognitive testing (Mini-Mental State Examination, Montreal Cognitive Assessment); magnetic resonance imaging shows hippocampal and cortical atrophy; positron emission tomography amyloid or tau imaging; cerebrospinal fluid or plasma biomarkers (decreased amyloid-beta 42, increased tau)
column9: Cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine) for mild to moderate disease; memantine (N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor antagonist) for moderate to severe disease; newer disease-modifying therapies: lecanemab and donanemab (anti-amyloid monoclonal antibodies) for mild cognitive impairment or mild dementia stage; nonpharmacologic: cognitive stimulation, caregiver support

column2: Adult with progressive asymmetric limb weakness, muscle atrophy, fasciculations, hyperreflexia, and bulbar symptoms without sensory loss; "upper and lower motor neuron signs together"
column3: Progressive degeneration of upper motor neurons in motor cortex and lower motor neurons in brainstem and spinal cord anterior horns; mechanisms include protein aggregation (transactive response DNA-binding protein 43, superoxide dismutase 1), glutamate excitotoxicity, oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction; 10 percent familial
column4: Incidence 1 to 3 per 100,000 per year; prevalence 4 to 6 per 100,000; mean age of onset 55 to 65 years; male to female ratio 1.5 to 1; 90 percent sporadic, 10 percent familial
column5: Upper motor neuron: spasticity, hyperreflexia, extensor plantar responses; Lower motor neuron: weakness, muscle atrophy, fasciculations, hyporeflexia; Bulbar: dysarthria, dysphagia, tongue atrophy and fasciculations; no sensory loss, no bowel or bladder dysfunction early, no eye movement abnormalities
column6: Progressive over months to years; median survival 3 to 5 years from symptom onset; 10 percent survive more than 10 years; bulbar onset has worse prognosis
column7: Multifocal motor neuropathy, cervical myelopathy with radiculopathy, inclusion body myositis, spinobulbar muscular atrophy, primary lateral sclerosis, progressive muscular atrophy, myasthenia gravis
column8: Electromyography and nerve conduction studies showing widespread denervation with normal sensory responses; magnetic resonance imaging of brain and spine to exclude structural lesions; revised El Escorial criteria (upper and lower motor neuron signs in multiple regions); elevated creatine kinase
column9: Riluzole (glutamate antagonist) modestly prolongs survival; edaravone (antioxidant) may slow decline; multidisciplinary care: noninvasive ventilation, percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy, physical therapy, speech therapy, palliative care

column2: Loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation with preserved proprioception and vibration; "can tell where limbs are but can't move them or feel pain"
column3: Ischemic injury to anterior two-thirds of spinal cord from anterior spinal artery occlusion; affects corticospinal tracts and spinothalamic tracts; dorsal columns (posterior one-third) spared
column4: Relatively rare; associated with aortic surgery, hypotension, anterior spinal artery thrombosis, disc herniation, hyperflexion injuries
column5: Complete motor paralysis below lesion; loss of pain and temperature sensation below lesion; preserved proprioception, vibration, two-point discrimination, and fine touch; bladder and bowel dysfunction
column6: Acute onset over minutes to hours with vascular causes; may be acute with trauma
column7: Central cord syndrome, complete spinal cord injury, spinal cord infarction, epidural hematoma, transverse myelitis
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging shows anterior cord signal abnormality (T2 hyperintensity in anterior two-thirds); diffusion-weighted imaging may show restricted diffusion with infarction; neurological examination
column9: Acute: supportive care, blood pressure augmentation for spinal cord perfusion; treat underlying cause (aortic repair, anticoagulation if thrombosis); Rehabilitation: physical and occupational therapy; Prognosis: poorest among incomplete cord syndromes

column2: Child or young adult with progressive headaches and vomiting; congenital form presents in infancy with macrocephaly; X-linked form in males with adducted thumbs
column3: Narrowing or obstruction of cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius between third and fourth ventricles; can be congenital due to genetic mutations such as L1CAM or acquired from infection, hemorrhage, tumor; results in dilation of lateral and third ventricles with normal fourth ventricle
column4: Most common cause of congenital obstructive hydrocephalus; X-linked hydrocephalus accounts for some cases; can present at any age from prenatal period through adulthood
column5: Infants: increasing head circumference, bulging fontanelle, irritability, vomiting, upgaze palsy; older patients: headache, nausea, vomiting, diplopia from sixth nerve palsy, cognitive decline, gait disturbance
column6: Congenital forms typically present in infancy or early childhood; acquired forms present subacutely after inciting event; can remain asymptomatic until adulthood in some cases
column7: Other causes of obstructive hydrocephalus such as posterior fossa tumor, tectal glioma, pineal region mass, vein of Galen malformation
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging shows dilated lateral and third ventricles with normal or small fourth ventricle; aqueductal narrowing or obstruction visible; cine magnetic resonance imaging cerebrospinal fluid flow studies confirm obstruction; prenatal ultrasound or fetal magnetic resonance imaging for prenatal diagnosis
column9: Endoscopic third ventriculostomy is standard treatment; ventriculoperitoneal shunt if endoscopic third ventriculostomy fails or is contraindicated; stereotactic prepontine stenting is alternative; treat underlying cause if tumor or mass present

column2: Adolescent or young adult with occipital headache worsened by Valsalva, syringomyelia causing cape-like sensory loss; cerebellar tonsillar herniation greater than or equal to 5 mm below foramen magnum
column3: Cerebellar tonsillar herniation through foramen magnum (greater than or equal to 5 mm); may be associated with syrinx (cystic cavity in spinal cord); causes CSF flow obstruction and compression of lower medulla; multifactorial etiology, possible genetic component
column4: Prevalence 0.9% for tonsillar descent greater than or equal to 5 mm on MRI in asymptomatic adults; female-to-male ratio 3.5:1; can be primary or secondary to connective tissue disorders
column5: Occipital or suboccipital headache (especially Valsalva-associated), numbness or weakness in hands/feet, oscillopsia, hearing problems, balance problems, downbeating nystagmus, sleep apnea, swallowing difficulty; syrinx causes cape-like sensory loss and weakness
column6: Can be congenital but often asymptomatic until adolescence or adulthood; symptoms may be progressive; syrinx can develop over time
column7: Chiari malformation type 2 (associated with myelomeningocele), other causes of headache, syringomyelia from other causes, posterior fossa tumors
column8: Brain and cervical spine MRI showing cerebellar tonsillar herniation greater than or equal to 5 mm below foramen magnum (McRae's line); peglike tonsillar shape; syrinx on cervical MRI; cardiac-gated CSF flow imaging shows compromised CSF dynamics
column9: Asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic: conservative management with observation; Symptomatic: posterior fossa decompression with duraplasty; syrinx may require separate treatment; avoid activities that increase intracranial pressure

column2: Ipsilateral third nerve palsy with contralateral tremor, ataxia, and hyperreflexia; "red nucleus plus third nerve"
column3: Midbrain lesion affecting oculomotor nerve fascicles, red nucleus, and superior cerebellar peduncle; most commonly due to posterior cerebral artery or basilar perforating artery occlusion; also caused by trauma, tumor, or hemorrhage
column4: Rare midbrain syndrome; typically affects middle-aged to older adults; vascular etiology most common
column5: Ipsilateral: third nerve palsy (ptosis, mydriasis, eye down and out); Contralateral: intention tremor, hemiataxia, dysmetria, hyperactive deep tendon reflexes, choreiform movements possible
column6: Acute onset with vascular causes (minutes to hours); subacute to chronic with mass lesions (days to weeks)
column7: Weber syndrome, Claude syndrome, other midbrain strokes, multiple sclerosis, brain tumor, arteriovenous malformation
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging with diffusion-weighted imaging shows midbrain lesion involving red nucleus and oculomotor fascicles; magnetic resonance angiography or computed tomography angiography to evaluate posterior circulation; vascular risk factor assessment
column9: Acute stroke: thrombolysis or thrombectomy if eligible; secondary stroke prevention with antiplatelet or anticoagulation; symptomatic tremor management: propranolol, primidone, or deep brain stimulation of ventral intermediate nucleus for refractory cases; physical therapy for ataxia

column2: Patient with descending paralysis, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia following consumption of home-canned foods or honey (infant); "flaccid paralysis that descends"
column3: Clostridium botulinum produces botulinum toxin (types A, B, E most common in humans); toxin irreversibly blocks acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junction by cleaving synaptosomal-associated protein 25; causes flaccid paralysis
column4: Rare; approximately 200 cases per year in United States; foodborne (home-canned foods, fermented fish), infant (honey, soil exposure in infants less than 12 months), wound (injection drug use), iatrogenic (cosmetic or therapeutic botulinum toxin)
column5: Cranial nerve palsies: diplopia, ptosis, dilated pupils, dysarthria, dysphagia, facial weakness; descending symmetric flaccid paralysis; no sensory loss; no fever; alert and oriented; autonomic: dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention; respiratory failure
column6: Foodborne: symptoms 12 to 36 hours after ingestion; progressive over days; recovery over weeks to months with supportive care
column7: Guillain-Barré syndrome (especially Miller Fisher variant), myasthenia gravis, stroke, tick paralysis, Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, organophosphate poisoning, shellfish poisoning
column8: Clinical diagnosis; confirmatory: detection of toxin in serum, stool, or food by mouse bioassay; electromyography shows brief, small, abundant motor unit action potentials with facilitation at high-frequency stimulation; normal nerve conduction studies
column9: Antitoxin: heptavalent botulism antitoxin for adults, botulism immune globulin for infants; supportive care: mechanical ventilation if respiratory failure; nasogastric feeding; bowel regimen; do not induce vomiting; antibiotics only for wound botulism (penicillin or metronidazole)

column2: Headache, fever, focal neurologic deficits (classic triad present in minority); history of dental infection, ear-nose-throat infection, or immunocompromise
column3: Focal pyogenic infection of brain parenchyma; oral cavity bacteria including anaerobes predominant pathogens; also Staphylococcus aureus and Enterobacteriaceae; predisposing factors include contiguous infection, trauma, hematogenous spread
column4: Incidence increasing, especially in elderly; affects 0.3-1.3 per 100,000 persons; immunocompromise present in 40%; dental and ear-nose-throat infections common predisposing conditions
column5: Headache (most common), focal neurologic deficits, fever, seizures, altered mental status, nausea and vomiting; classic triad of headache, fever, and focal deficit present in minority
column6: Subacute onset over days to weeks; can be acute in some cases
column7: Meningitis, encephalitis, brain tumor, stroke, subdural empyema
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging with contrast showing ring-enhancing lesion with restricted diffusion; neurosurgical aspiration or excision for diagnosis and source control; aerobic and anaerobic cultures
column9: Neurosurgical aspiration or excision combined with prolonged antibiotics (typically 4-8 weeks); empiric regimen: ceftriaxone plus metronidazole plus vancomycin; adjust based on culture results and source

column2: Hemisection of spinal cord (classically from penetrating trauma like stab wound) with ipsilateral motor weakness and proprioception loss, contralateral pain and temperature loss
column3: Unilateral spinal cord injury affecting ipsilateral corticospinal tract (motor), dorsal columns (proprioception, vibration), and contralateral spinothalamic tract (pain, temperature sensation crosses at spinal level)
column4: Rare in pure form; more commonly presents as Brown-Séquard-plus syndrome with features of other incomplete syndromes; penetrating trauma, tumors, disc herniation, multiple sclerosis
column5: Ipsilateral: motor weakness, loss of proprioception and vibration sense below lesion; Contralateral: loss of pain and temperature sensation one to two levels below lesion; Bilateral: all sensory modalities lost at level of lesion
column6: Acute onset with trauma; gradual onset with compressive or inflammatory lesions
column7: Central cord syndrome, anterior cord syndrome, complete spinal cord injury, spinal cord tumor, transverse myelitis, epidural abscess
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging shows unilateral spinal cord lesion; computed tomography for bony injury; neurological examination documenting lateralized findings
column9: Acute trauma: surgical decompression if indicated; Tumor or abscess: surgical resection or drainage; Rehabilitation: physical therapy; Prognosis: best recovery among incomplete cord syndromes

column2: Young patient with unilateral headache, neck pain, and Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) followed by stroke; history of minor neck trauma or chiropractic manipulation; "beauty parlor stroke"
column3: Intimal tear or rupture of vasa vasorum leads to intramural hematoma formation in arterial wall; subintimal dissection causes stenosis while subadventitial dissection causes aneurysmal degeneration; typically occurs 2 centimeters distal to carotid bifurcation; stroke occurs via artery-to-artery thromboembolism from intraluminal thrombus or arterial occlusion
column4: Accounts for 2 percent of all ischemic strokes but up to 25 percent of strokes in adults under 50 years; incidence 2.6 to 3.0 per 100,000 people; mean age at diagnosis 45 years; slightly more common in men; associated with connective tissue disorders (Ehlers-Danlos type 4, Marfan syndrome), fibromuscular dysplasia (15 percent association), recent infection, minor trauma
column5: Unilateral headache (65 percent, temporal or frontal), neck pain (50 percent), partial Horner syndrome (25 percent), pulsatile tinnitus (8 percent), cranial nerve palsies (12 percent, especially hypoglossal); followed by focal neurological deficits (hemiparesis, aphasia, visual disturbances) in 50 to 95 percent; may present with isolated pain without ischemia (8 to 12 percent)
column6: Pain and local symptoms typically precede cerebral ischemia by hours to days; stroke risk highest in first few weeks; recurrent dissection rare (less than 2 percent at 3 months); most patients have favorable prognosis with treatment
column7: Large vessel atherosclerotic stroke, cardioembolic stroke, migraine with aura, cluster headache, temporal arteritis, fibromuscular dysplasia, intracranial aneurysm, vertebral artery dissection
column8: CT angiography or MR angiography of head and neck (preferred initial tests); imaging hallmarks include intimal flap, intramural hematoma, double lumen, dissecting aneurysm, tapering stenosis or occlusion; MRI with fat-suppressed T1-weighted images shows crescent-shaped intramural hematoma; carotid ultrasound not recommended as initial test due to limited sensitivity; digital subtraction angiography reserved for atypical cases
column9: Intravenous alteplase and endovascular thrombectomy if eligible for acute stroke; antithrombotic therapy for 3 to 6 months (either anticoagulation or antiplatelet therapy, choice individualized based on bleeding risk and high-risk features); anticoagulation preferred for severe stenosis, occlusion, or intraluminal thrombus in low bleeding risk patients; antiplatelet therapy for patients with hemorrhagic transformation or high bleeding risk; avoid chiropractic neck manipulation;endovascular or surgical intervention reserved for refractory cases

column2: Fever, headache, and bilateral progressive ophthalmoplegia with periorbital edema following facial infection or sinusitis; "painful eye with cranial nerve six palsy"
column3: Septic thrombophlebitis of cavernous sinus from spread of infection (most commonly sinusitis or facial infection); Staphylococcus aureus most common pathogen; thrombosis obstructs venous drainage and affects cranial nerves three, four, five (ophthalmic and maxillary divisions), and six within sinus
column4: Rare condition; most common antecedent is sinusitis or facial infection several days prior; other causes include maxillofacial trauma, surgery, thrombophilia, dehydration
column5: Fever, severe headache, periorbital edema, chemosis, ptosis, ophthalmoplegia (cranial nerve six affected first causing lateral rectus palsy, then cranial nerves three and four), vision changes; bilateral involvement in 70 percent of cases; may have altered mental status, seizures
column6: Progressive over days; initially unilateral then becomes bilateral within 24 to 48 hours
column7: Orbital cellulitis, orbital abscess, cerebral venous thrombosis, meningitis, brain abscess, septic emboli
column8: Computed tomography head and orbits with intravenous contrast delayed phase imaging; magnetic resonance venography has highest sensitivity; blood cultures positive in up to 70 percent; elevated inflammatory markers
column9: Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics (vancomycin plus third or fourth generation cephalosporin or carbapenem); anticoagulation with heparin; neurosurgery and infectious disease consultation; may require surgical drainage of source

column2: Elderly patient with hyperextension neck injury after fall presenting with upper extremity weakness greater than lower extremity weakness; "arms worse than legs"
column3: Injury to central gray matter and crossing spinothalamic fibers in cervical spinal cord; lateral corticospinal tract fibers to upper extremities are more centrally located than those to lower extremities; often occurs with underlying cervical spondylosis
column4: Most common incomplete spinal cord injury syndrome; typically affects older adults with degenerative cervical spine disease; younger patients may have fracture-dislocation or disc herniation
column5: Upper extremity weakness (especially hands) greater than lower extremity weakness; variable sensory loss with suspended sensory level possible; bladder dysfunction (usually urinary retention) may occur; tendon reflexes lost at lesion level
column6: Acute onset with trauma; may improve over weeks to months with rehabilitation
column7: Anterior cord syndrome, Brown-Séquard syndrome, complete spinal cord injury, cervical disc herniation, epidural hematoma
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging of cervical spine shows central cord signal abnormality (T2 hyperintensity); computed tomography to evaluate for fractures; neurological examination documenting motor and sensory levels
column9: Acute: high-dose methylprednisolone controversial; surgical decompression timing debated (early versus delayed); Rehabilitation: physical and occupational therapy; Prognosis: generally favorable with lower extremity recovery better than upper extremity

column2: Elderly patient with multiple lobar microbleeds on MRI, cognitive decline, and cortical superficial siderosis; may be asymptomatic or present with transient focal neurological episodes
column3: Beta-amyloid deposition in walls of cortical and leptomeningeal small and medium-sized arteries and arterioles; progresses through stages: initial vascular amyloid deposition, alteration of cerebrovascular physiology, non-hemorrhagic brain injury, hemorrhagic lesions
column4: Common age-related small vessel pathology; prevalence increases with age; present in 10 to 40 percent of elderly individuals at autopsy; more common in patients with Alzheimer disease
column5: May be asymptomatic; cognitive impairment or dementia; transient focal neurological episodes (amyloid spells); lobar intracerebral hemorrhage; convexity subarachnoid hemorrhage
column6: Develops over two to three decades; progression from subclinical pathology to clinical manifestation occurs in sequential stages; once symptomatic hemorrhage occurs, high risk of recurrence
column7: Hypertensive small vessel disease, other causes of cognitive impairment, primary central nervous system vasculitis, reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome
column8: Boston Criteria version 2.0: probable diagnosis requires age 50 years or older with at least two strictly lobar hemorrhagic lesions on MRI (intracerebral hemorrhage, cerebral microbleeds, cortical superficial siderosis, convexity subarachnoid hemorrhage) or one lobar hemorrhagic lesion plus white matter features; definite diagnosis requires pathological confirmation
column9: No disease-modifying treatment currently available; strict blood pressure control; avoidance of anticoagulation and antiplatelet agents when possible; management of cognitive symptoms; fall precautions; treatment of acute hemorrhage when occurs

column2: Elderly patient with long-standing hypertension presenting with deep intracerebral hemorrhage
column3: Small aneurysmal dilations (50 to 900 micrometers) of penetrating arteries in basal ganglia and brainstem; result from chronic hypertensive damage causing vessel wall weakening; represent manifestation of severe cerebral small vessel disease
column4: Rare finding; predominantly seen in elderly individuals with multiple cerebrovascular comorbidities including hypertension and cerebral amyloid angiopathy; found in less than 0.5 percent of routine autopsies
column5: Usually asymptomatic until rupture; when symptomatic, presents with features of deep intracerebral hemorrhage or microhemorrhage; may have associated microinfarcts in vicinity
column6: Develop over years to decades of chronic hypertension; rupture leads to acute hemorrhage
column7: Hypertensive arteriopathy without aneurysm formation, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, other small vessel diseases
column8: Histopathological diagnosis on autopsy or surgical specimen; not visible on standard neuroimaging; MRI may show associated microhemorrhages or microinfarcts in basal ganglia
column9: Management focuses on controlling underlying hypertension and cerebrovascular risk factors; no specific treatment for microaneurysms themselves; treatment of resulting hemorrhage follows standard intracerebral hemorrhage protocols

column2: Child or young adult with distal leg weakness, foot drop, high arches (pes cavus), and hammer toes; "stork legs" or "inverted champagne bottle legs"
column3: Heterogeneous group of inherited peripheral neuropathies; most common type 1A due to duplication of peripheral myelin protein 22 gene causing demyelination; type 2 involves axonal degeneration; affects motor and sensory nerves
column4: Most common inherited neuropathy; prevalence 1 in 2500; type 1A (demyelinating) most common subtype (70 percent); autosomal dominant inheritance most common; onset typically childhood to young adulthood
column5: Distal leg weakness and atrophy (foot drop, steppage gait), pes cavus, hammer toes, distal sensory loss (glove-and-stocking), absent ankle reflexes, hand weakness and atrophy in later stages; slowly progressive; minimal pain; normal life expectancy
column6: Onset typically first or second decade; slowly progressive over decades; wheelchair dependence rare except in severe forms
column7: Hereditary neuropathy with liability to pressure palsies, distal spinal muscular atrophy, chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, other hereditary neuropathies, muscular dystrophy
column8: Nerve conduction studies: type 1 (demyelinating) shows uniform slowing (median motor nerve conduction velocity less than 38 meters per second); type 2 (axonal) shows reduced amplitudes with normal velocities; genetic testing confirms diagnosis; nerve biopsy shows onion bulb formation in type 1
column9: No cure; ankle-foot orthoses for foot drop; physical therapy to maintain strength and range of motion; occupational therapy; surgical correction of foot deformities; pain management if needed; genetic counseling

column2: Ipsilateral third nerve palsy with contralateral ataxia; "red nucleus without tremor" (compared to Benedikt)
column3: Ventromedial midbrain lesion affecting oculomotor nerve nucleus or fascicles and red nucleus or superior cerebellar peduncle; most commonly due to ischemic stroke from posterior cerebral artery or basilar perforating branches; also neurocysticercosis, neuro-Behcet disease
column4: Very rare; more common in adults but pediatric cases reported; vascular etiology predominates in adults
column5: Ipsilateral: third nerve palsy (ptosis, mydriasis, impaired adduction, elevation, and depression of eye); Contralateral: hemiataxia, dysmetria, intention tremor less prominent than Benedikt syndrome
column6: Acute onset with stroke (minutes to hours); subacute with infectious or inflammatory causes (days to weeks)
column7: Benedikt syndrome, Weber syndrome, other brainstem strokes, multiple sclerosis, neurocysticercosis, neuro-Behcet disease
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging shows ventromedial midbrain infarction; magnetic resonance angiography for vascular assessment; cerebrospinal fluid analysis if infectious or inflammatory etiology suspected; serology for Behcet disease or neurocysticercosis if indicated
column9: Acute stroke: thrombolysis or thrombectomy if eligible; secondary prevention with antiplatelet or anticoagulation; treat underlying cause: albendazole and steroids for neurocysticercosis, immunosuppression for neuro-Behcet; physical therapy for ataxia

column2: Elderly patient with gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and dementia; "wet, wobbly, and wacky" triad; ventriculomegaly out of proportion to atrophy
column3: Impaired cerebrospinal fluid absorption at arachnoid granulations; no obstruction within ventricular system; glymphatic dysfunction and neuroinflammation contribute; can result from prior hemorrhage, infection, or be idiopathic
column4: Prevalence approximately 85 per 100,000 globally in adults; idiopathic normal pressure hydrocephalus affects elderly population; post-hemorrhagic and post-infectious forms occur across age groups
column5: Gait disturbance with magnetic or shuffling gait, urinary incontinence, cognitive impairment or dementia, headache; Evans ratio greater than 0.3; disproportionately enlarged subarachnoid space hydrocephalus pattern on imaging
column6: Chronic progressive course over months to years in idiopathic normal pressure hydrocephalus; subacute in secondary forms following hemorrhage or infection
column7: Obstructive hydrocephalus, Alzheimer disease, Parkinson disease, vascular dementia, brain atrophy with aging
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging or computed tomography showing ventriculomegaly with Evans ratio greater than 0.3, callosal angle less than 90 degrees, sulcal effacement at vertex; lumbar puncture safe with normal opening pressure; high volume tap or external lumbar drain trial may predict shunt responsiveness
column9: Ventriculoperitoneal shunt with programmable valve; ventriculoatrial shunt if peritoneum unavailable; lumbar-peritoneal shunt in select cases; treat underlying cause if secondary

column2: Child with recurrent injuries, burns, fractures, and self-mutilation without pain perception; normal intelligence and other sensory modalities
column3: Autosomal recessive loss-of-function mutation in sodium voltage-gated channel alpha subunit 9 gene; complete loss of channel function prevents action potential generation in nociceptive neurons; pain sensation absent while other sensory modalities preserved
column4: Extremely rare; fewer than 100 cases reported worldwide; onset from birth; equal gender distribution
column5: Complete absence of pain perception from birth; recurrent unnoticed injuries, burns, fractures, joint damage; self-mutilation (tongue biting, finger biting); corneal scarring from eye trauma; normal touch, temperature discrimination, proprioception; normal intelligence; anhidrosis common
column6: Present from birth; lifelong; progressive joint destruction and complications from repeated trauma
column7: Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy types, congenital indifference to pain (central processing disorder), leprosy, syringomyelia, familial dysautonomia
column8: Genetic testing showing homozygous or compound heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in sodium voltage-gated channel alpha subunit 9; nerve biopsy shows absence of small unmyelinated C fibers; quantitative sensory testing confirms absent pain perception; normal nerve conduction studies for large fibers
column9: No cure; preventive measures: protective equipment, environmental modifications, frequent examinations for injuries; patient and family education; treatment of injuries and infections; orthopedic management of joint damage; psychological support

column2: Intracellular swelling after ischemic stroke, trauma, or metabolic insult; restricted diffusion on magnetic resonance imaging
column3: Energy failure leads to sodium-potassium-ATPase pump dysfunction; sodium influx followed by chloride entry via SLC26A11 channel; resultant sodium chloride and water accumulation causes neuronal and glial swelling
column4: Occurs in cerebral ischemia, traumatic brain injury, intoxications, metabolic disorders, and hyponatremia
column5: Altered mental status, seizures, focal neurologic deficits; symptoms reflect underlying brain injury and increased intracranial pressure
column6: Develops within minutes to hours after initial insult; can progress rapidly
column7: Vasogenic edema, hemorrhage, mass effect from other causes
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging with diffusion-weighted imaging shows restricted diffusion and decreased apparent diffusion coefficient; computed tomography shows loss of gray-white differentiation
column9: Treat underlying cause; osmotic therapy with hypertonic saline or mannitol for elevated intracranial pressure; avoid hypotonic fluids; maintain adequate cerebral perfusion pressure

column2: Newborn with congenital heart disease, hypocalcemic seizures, and recurrent infections
column3: Microdeletion of chromosome 22q11.2 (most common) or 10p; haploinsufficiency of TBX1 and other genes affects pharyngeal pouch development
column4: 1 in 2,000 to 4,000 live births; most cases de novo deletions
column5: Cardiac malformations (conotruncal defects), thymic hypoplasia or aplasia with T-cell immunodeficiency, hypoparathyroidism with hypocalcemia, velopharyngeal insufficiency, characteristic facies, renal anomalies (30 percent), neurodevelopmental delays, psychiatric disorders
column6: Congenital; immunodeficiency and hypocalcemia manifest in infancy; psychiatric manifestations emerge later in life
column7: CHARGE syndrome, VACTERL association, other 22q11.2 deletion syndromes, isolated conotruncal cardiac defects
column8: Fluorescence in situ hybridization or chromosomal microarray for 22q11.2 deletion; flow cytometry for T-cell counts; calcium and parathyroid hormone levels; echocardiography; renal ultrasound
column9: Calcium and vitamin D supplementation for hypoparathyroidism; cardiac surgery as needed; immunoglobulin replacement if significant antibody deficiency; live vaccines contraindicated if severe T-cell deficiency; thymus transplantation in complete DiGeorge

column2: Altered mental status with fever; behavioral changes, speech disturbances, seizures; herpes simplex virus most common identified cause
column3: Infection and inflammation of brain parenchyma causing abnormal cerebral function; herpes simplex virus type 1 causes 90% of identified viral cases; also enteroviruses, West Nile virus, varicella zoster virus
column4: Definite or probable cause identified in only 16% of cases; herpes simplex virus most commonly identified pathogen; affects all ages but varies by pathogen
column5: Altered mental status, fever, behavioral or speech disturbances, sensory or motor deficits, seizures, headache; may have focal neurologic signs
column6: Acute to subacute onset over hours to days
column7: Meningitis, brain abscess, autoimmune encephalitis, metabolic encephalopathy, stroke
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging brain; lumbar puncture with cerebrospinal fluid polymerase chain reaction for herpes simplex virus, varicella zoster virus, enteroviruses, West Nile virus; electroencephalogram; autoimmune antibody panel including anti-N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor
column9: Empiric acyclovir 10 mg per kg every 8 hours intravenously immediately; continue until second herpes simplex virus polymerase chain reaction negative if initially negative; increase dose for varicella zoster virus; supportive care for other viral causes; immunotherapy for autoimmune causes

column2: Newborn with visible midline cranial mass that enlarges with crying; posterior (occipital) most common; may have CSF leak, hydrocephalus; "brain herniates through skull defect, posterior location"
column3: Neural tube defect characterized by herniation of brain parenchyma and meninges through bony skull defect; failure of neural tube closure during embryonic development (days 26 to 28 of gestation); multifactorial etiology involving genetic and environmental factors including folate deficiency
column4: 1 in 5,000 to 1 in 40,000 live births; higher incidence in Southeast Asia; posterior (occipital) encephaloceles account for 75 to 94% of cases in Western populations; frontoethmoidal more common in Southeast Asia; female predominance (approximately 60 to 70%)
column5: Visible cranial mass (enlarges with crying or Valsalva), CSF leak, hydrocephalus (50 to 90% in posterior types), developmental delay, seizures, visual impairment; nasal obstruction if basal or frontoethmoidal; associated anomalies include cardiac defects (35%), Dandy-Walker malformation, Chiari III malformation, microcephaly, ventriculomegaly
column6: Congenital malformation present at birth; prenatal diagnosis possible via ultrasound in second trimester; hydrocephalus may develop before or after surgical repair; developmental outcomes depend on location, size, brain tissue involvement, and associated anomalies
column7: Meningocele (no brain tissue), cephalohematoma, hemangioma, dermoid cyst, nasal glioma, other midline cranial masses, neural tube defects
column8: Prenatal ultrasound showing cranial defect with herniated contents; postnatal CT or MRI to define bony defect, herniated contents (brain parenchyma, ventricles, vessels), associated malformations; echocardiography to evaluate for cardiac anomalies; genetic evaluation if syndromic features present
column9: Surgical repair with excision of herniated tissue and dural closure, typically within first days to weeks of life; ventriculoperitoneal shunt for hydrocephalus (needed in 50 to 70% of posterior cases); multidisciplinary care including neurosurgery, plastic surgery, ophthalmology; prenatal counseling; folic acid supplementation (400 to 800 micrograms daily) for prevention in future pregnancies

column2: Young patient with head trauma, brief loss of consciousness, lucid interval, then rapid deterioration; "talk and die"
column3: Arterial bleeding (typically middle meningeal artery) from temporal bone fracture; blood accumulates between skull and dura; does not cross suture lines
column4: More common in younger patients; associated with temporal bone fractures and high-impact trauma
column5: Initial loss of consciousness followed by lucid interval (classic but not always present), then rapid neurologic deterioration with headache, vomiting, altered mental status, contralateral hemiparesis, ipsilateral pupil dilation (uncal herniation)
column6: Acute onset after trauma; lucid interval may last minutes to hours before deterioration
column7: Subdural hematoma, subarachnoid hemorrhage, traumatic brain injury, cerebral contusion, skull fracture
column8: Noncontrast computed tomography head shows biconvex (lentiform) hyperdense collection that does not cross suture lines; may see associated skull fracture
column9: Emergent neurosurgical evacuation for significant hematomas or neurologic deterioration; small hematomas in stable patients may be observed with serial imaging

column2: Child or young adult with brief episodes (seconds to minutes) of ataxia and dysarthria triggered by startle, stress, or exercise; myokymia between episodes
column3: Autosomal dominant mutation in potassium voltage-gated channel subfamily A member 1 gene on chromosome 12; encodes voltage-gated potassium channel; mutation causes neuronal hyperexcitability in cerebellum and peripheral nerves
column4: Rare; prevalence unknown; onset typically in childhood or adolescence; equal gender distribution
column5: Brief episodes (seconds to minutes) of ataxia, dysarthria, vertigo, blurred vision; triggered by sudden movement, startle, stress, exercise; continuous myokymia (fine muscle twitching) especially periocular; normal between attacks initially; may develop persistent ataxia with age
column6: Episodes begin in childhood; frequency variable (daily to monthly); individual episodes last seconds to minutes; may develop progressive baseline ataxia over decades
column7: Episodic ataxia type 2, paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia, multiple sclerosis, vestibular migraine, hyperekplexia, myotonia congenita
column8: Genetic testing for potassium voltage-gated channel subfamily A member 1 mutations; electromyography shows myokymic discharges; magnetic resonance imaging brain typically normal; acetazolamide trial may be diagnostic and therapeutic
column9: Acetazolamide (carbonic anhydrase inhibitor) reduces attack frequency and severity in most patients; carbamazepine or phenytoin alternatives; avoid triggers when possible

column2: Bilateral loss of voluntary control of facial, pharyngeal, lingual, and masticatory muscles with preserved reflexive and automatic functions; "anterior opercular syndrome, facio-pharyngo-glosso-masticatory diplegia"
column3: Bilateral lesions of anterior opercular regions (frontal and parietal opercula) causing cortical pseudobulbar palsy; disrupts voluntary motor pathways while preserving automatic and emotional pathways; causes include bilateral strokes, meningoencephalitis, perisylvian dysgenesis, epileptic disorders, brain abscess
column4: Very rare; can be congenital (perisylvian dysgenesis) or acquired; acquired form typically from bilateral vascular events in adults or meningoencephalitis in children; also called Worster-Drought syndrome in children
column5: Anarthria or severe dysarthria, inability to voluntarily move facial muscles, tongue, or pharyngeal muscles on command; preserved automatic functions: laughing, crying, coughing, yawning; drooling, dysphagia, difficulty with mastication; patient alert and cognitively intact
column6: Acute with stroke or infection (hours to days); congenital form present from birth; may be persistent or intermittent with epileptic variant
column7: Bulbar palsy (lower motor neuron), other pseudobulbar palsy causes, locked-in syndrome, severe dysarthria from other causes, bilateral facial nerve palsy
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging shows bilateral anterior opercular lesions (frontal and parietal opercula); electroencephalography if epileptic etiology suspected; cerebrospinal fluid analysis for infectious causes; clinical examination demonstrating automatic-voluntary dissociation
column9: Treat underlying cause: stroke prevention, antibiotics for meningoencephalitis, antiepileptic drugs for epileptic variant; speech therapy; feeding support (nasogastric tube or percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy if needed); prognosis variable, often favorable with treatment

column2: Ipsilateral sixth and seventh nerve palsies, conjugate gaze palsy toward lesion, and contralateral hemiparesis; "Millard-Gubler plus gaze palsy"
column3: Dorsal pontine tegmentum lesion affecting abducens nucleus (causing ipsilateral lateral rectus palsy and conjugate gaze palsy), facial nerve fascicles, and corticospinal tract; most commonly due to pontine infarction; also demyelination, hemorrhage
column4: Rare; affects adults with cerebrovascular risk factors; less common than ventral pontine syndromes
column5: Ipsilateral: conjugate gaze palsy (eyes deviate away from lesion), lateral rectus palsy, peripheral facial palsy, possible Horner syndrome; Contralateral: hemiparesis, hemisensory loss possible
column6: Acute onset with stroke (minutes to hours); subacute with other etiologies
column7: Millard-Gubler syndrome (no gaze palsy), other pontine strokes, multiple sclerosis, pontine hemorrhage, basilar artery occlusion
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging shows dorsal pontine tegmental lesion; magnetic resonance angiography for vascular evaluation; diffusion-weighted imaging for acute stroke
column9: Acute stroke: thrombolysis or thrombectomy if eligible; secondary prevention; supportive care; physical and occupational therapy

column2: Patient with ascending symmetric weakness and areflexia following recent respiratory or gastrointestinal infection (especially Campylobacter jejuni); "paralysis that ascends"
column3: Acute immune-mediated demyelinating or axonal polyneuropathy; molecular mimicry between infectious agents (Campylobacter jejuni, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus) and peripheral nerve components; antibodies against gangliosides (GM1, GD1a, GQ1b) cause nerve damage
column4: Incidence 1 to 2 per 100,000 per year; affects all ages with slight male predominance; 60 to 70 percent have antecedent infection 1 to 3 weeks prior
column5: Progressive symmetric ascending weakness (legs before arms), areflexia or hyporeflexia, paresthesias, back pain; respiratory muscle weakness in 25 percent; autonomic dysfunction (arrhythmias, blood pressure lability); Miller Fisher variant: ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, areflexia
column6: Progressive phase: worsens over days to 4 weeks (nadir by 2 weeks in 50 percent, by 4 weeks in 90 percent); Plateau phase: 2 to 4 weeks; Recovery: months to years
column7: Myasthenia gravis, botulism, tick paralysis, acute intermittent porphyria, transverse myelitis, spinal cord compression, chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, critical illness polyneuropathy
column8: Cerebrospinal fluid shows albuminocytologic dissociation (elevated protein greater than 45 milligrams per deciliter, normal white blood cell count less than 10 per microliter); nerve conduction studies show demyelination or axonal loss; spirometry to assess respiratory function
column9: Intravenous immunoglobulin (0.4 grams per kilogram per day for 5 days) or plasma exchange; supportive care in intensive care unit if respiratory compromise; monitor forced vital capacity and negative inspiratory force; mechanical ventilation if needed; thromboprophylaxis; pain management

column2: Sudden severe headache ("worst headache of life"), vomiting, altered consciousness, focal deficits; often occurs during exertion or with severe hypertension
column3: Acute vessel rupture causing intraparenchymal, intraventricular, or subarachnoid blood accumulation. Causes: hypertension (most common), cerebral amyloid angiopathy, vascular malformations, anticoagulation, cocaine, trauma
column4: 10% intracerebral hemorrhage, 3% subarachnoid hemorrhage of all strokes in the United States. Intracerebral hemorrhage more common in older adults, hypertension, anticoagulation use
column5: Severe headache, vomiting, depressed level of consciousness, focal neurological deficits, seizures, neck stiffness (subarachnoid hemorrhage). Signs of increased intracranial pressure: bradycardia, hypertension, irregular respirations
column6: Acute onset (seconds to minutes). Symptoms may progress over minutes to hours due to hematoma expansion
column7: Ischemic stroke, subarachnoid hemorrhage, subdural hematoma, epidural hematoma, brain tumor with hemorrhage, venous sinus thrombosis, reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome
column8: Noncontrast computed tomography brain (shows acute blood immediately). Magnetic resonance imaging (gradient echo or susceptibility-weighted imaging detects blood). Computed tomography angiography or magnetic resonance angiography or digital subtraction angiography to identify vascular malformations or aneurysms. Coagulation studies. Lumbar puncture if subarachnoid hemorrhage suspected and imaging negative
column9: Blood pressure control: target systolic blood pressure 140 millimeters of mercury for intracerebral hemorrhage. Reverse anticoagulation immediately (vitamin K, prothrombin complex concentrate, idarucizumab, andexanet alfa as appropriate). Neurosurgical consultation for hematoma evacuation if indicated. Intracranial pressure management. Admit to intensive care or stroke unit. Seizure prophylaxis if indicated

column2: Newborn with delayed passage of meconium (greater than 48 hours), abdominal distension, bilious vomiting; "no meconium, big belly"; gushing of stool with rectal exam; may present with enterocolitis
column3: Congenital absence of ganglion cells (aganglionosis) in myenteric and submucosal plexuses; failure of cranial-caudal migration of neural crest cells during embryonic development; aganglionic segment cannot relax, causing functional obstruction; most commonly affects rectosigmoid (80%); genetic mutations in RET proto-oncogene (most common), EDNRB, and others
column4: Incidence 1 in 5000 live births; male to female ratio 4:1; associated with Down syndrome (trisomy 21), Waardenburg syndrome, Mowat-Wilson syndrome, congenital central hypoventilation syndrome; familial in 20% of cases
column5: Neonatal: delayed meconium passage (greater than 48 hours in 90%), abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, feeding intolerance; Older children: chronic constipation, failure to thrive, abdominal distension; Hirschsprung-associated enterocolitis: fever, explosive diarrhea, abdominal distension (life-threatening, 6-60% of patients); gushing of stool with rectal examination; absence of fecal soiling
column6: Symptoms present from birth or early infancy; 80% diagnosed in neonatal period; enterocolitis can occur at any time before or after surgery; chronic symptoms if diagnosis delayed
column7: Functional constipation (normal rectal exam, soiling present), meconium plug syndrome, meconium ileus (cystic fibrosis), intestinal atresia, hypothyroidism, other causes of neonatal intestinal obstruction
column8: Contrast enema shows transition zone between dilated proximal bowel and narrow distal aganglionic segment; rectal suction biopsy (gold standard): absence of ganglion cells, increased acetylcholinesterase staining; anorectal manometry: absence of rectoanal inhibitory reflex
column9: Rectal decompression with washouts; antibiotics for enterocolitis; definitive treatment: surgical resection of aganglionic segment with pull-through procedure (Swenson, Soave, or Duhamel); may require temporary colostomy; long-term management of postoperative complications (enterocolitis, constipation, soiling)

column2: Newborn with cyclopia, proboscis above single eye, or hypotelorism with midline facial defects; "the face predicts the brain"
column3: Failure of prosencephalon to divide into two hemispheres during 5th gestational week due to defective neural induction and patterning; may be caused by genetic mutations, chromosomal abnormalities, or teratogens
column4: 1 in 10,000 to 1 in 16,000 live births; most severe forms result in fetal demise
column5: Spectrum from alobar (most severe: cyclopia, proboscis, single ventricle) to lobar (least severe: hypotelorism, cleft lip/palate, single maxillary central incisor); microcephaly or hydrocephalus, intellectual disability, seizures, endocrine dysfunction
column6: Congenital malformation present at birth; severe forms often lethal in infancy; milder forms may survive into teens with severe developmental delays
column7: Aprosencephaly, atelencephaly, septo-optic dysplasia, other midline brain malformations, chromosomal syndromes
column8: Prenatal ultrasound or MRI showing absent or incomplete interhemispheric fissure, fused thalami, monoventricle; postnatal brain MRI; karyotype to exclude chromosomal causes; genetic testing
column9: Supportive care including seizure management, endocrine replacement therapy, feeding support, management of hydrocephalus if present; no curative treatment

column2: Unilateral miosis, ptosis, anhidrosis; "small pupil, droopy eyelid, no sweat"; may have heterochromia iridis if congenital; associated with neck trauma, neuroblastoma in children, lung cancer in adults
column3: Disruption of oculosympathetic pathway at any point from hypothalamus to eye; first-order neuron (central): hypothalamus to spinal cord; second-order neuron (preganglionic): spinal cord to superior cervical ganglion; third-order neuron (postganglionic): superior cervical ganglion to eye; causes include trauma, tumor (neuroblastoma, Pancoast tumor), dissection, iatrogenic injury
column4: Rare; congenital cases often associated with birth trauma; acquired cases in children most commonly from neuroblastoma (50% of cases); in adults associated with lung cancer, carotid dissection, iatrogenic injury; affects all ages
column5: Classic triad: miosis (small pupil), ptosis (drooping eyelid), anhidrosis (absent sweating); anhidrosis distribution depends on lesion location (facial if preganglionic, none if postganglionic); heterochromia iridis (lighter affected iris) if congenital; enophthalmos (apparent, not true); dilation lag in affected pupil in dim light
column6: Congenital: present from birth; Acquired: acute onset with trauma or dissection; insidious with tumor; symptoms persist unless underlying cause treated
column7: Physiologic anisocoria, third nerve palsy (has dilated pupil, not constricted), Adie tonic pupil, pharmacologic miosis, iris trauma
column8: Clinical diagnosis; pharmacologic testing: cocaine test (affected pupil fails to dilate) or apraclonidine test (affected pupil dilates paradoxically); imaging based on suspected location: brain and cervical spine magnetic resonance imaging for central and preganglionic lesions; chest imaging for preganglionic lesions; neck imaging for all acquired cases; urine catecholamines and abdominal imaging in children to exclude neuroblastoma
column9: Treat underlying cause; neuroblastoma: chemotherapy, surgery, radiation; carotid dissection: anticoagulation or antiplatelet therapy; tumor resection if appropriate; no specific treatment for ptosis or miosis unless cosmetically desired

column2: Adult with progressive chorea, psychiatric symptoms, and family history of similar illness; "autosomal dominant chorea with anticipation"
column3: Autosomal dominant trinucleotide repeat expansion (cytosine-adenine-guanine greater than 36 repeats) in huntingtin gene on chromosome 4; mutant huntingtin protein causes selective neuronal loss in striatum (caudate and putamen) and cortex; genetic anticipation occurs (earlier onset with paternal transmission)
column4: Prevalence 5 to 10 per 100,000 in populations of European descent; mean age of onset 35 to 45 years; juvenile onset (less than 20 years) in 5 to 10 percent
column5: Motor: chorea (involuntary, irregular, flowing movements), dystonia, rigidity (in juvenile form), bradykinesia, impaired coordination, dysphagia; Psychiatric: depression, irritability, apathy, psychosis, suicidal ideation; Cognitive: executive dysfunction, impaired attention, dementia
column6: Insidious onset; progressive over 15 to 20 years; inverse correlation between repeat length and age of onset; death typically from aspiration pneumonia or other complications
column7: Benign hereditary chorea, neuroacanthocytosis, Wilson disease, chorea-acanthocytosis, dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy, drug-induced chorea, Sydenham chorea
column8: Genetic testing showing cytosine-adenine-guanine repeat expansion greater than 36 (36 to 39 reduced penetrance, 40 or more full penetrance); magnetic resonance imaging shows caudate atrophy with enlarged frontal horns (boxcar ventricles); positron emission tomography shows striatal hypometabolism
column9: Symptomatic treatment: tetrabenazine or deutetrabenazine for chorea (vesicular monoamine transporter 2 inhibitors); antipsychotics for psychiatric symptoms; antidepressants for depression; physical therapy, speech therapy; genetic counseling for family members

column2: Newborn with lethargy, vomiting, and respiratory alkalosis 24-48 hours after first feeding; "protein avoidance" in older patients
column3: Impaired ammonia detoxification via urea cycle (primary defects in enzymes or transporters) or secondary inhibition (liver failure, portosystemic shunting, drugs, infections with urease-producing organisms). Ammonia is neurotoxic, causing astrocyte swelling and cerebral edema
column4: Most common in neonates with urea cycle disorders; can present at any age. Acquired causes (liver failure, portosystemic shunts) more common in adults
column5: Neuropsychiatric symptoms: altered mental status, lethargy, somnolence, vomiting, seizures, coma, tachypnea with respiratory alkalosis. Chronic: developmental delay, cognitive deficits, protein avoidance, psychiatric symptoms
column6: Acute: hours to days (medical emergency). Chronic: insidious onset with episodic decompensation triggered by infection, fasting, high protein intake, or stress
column7: Sepsis, intracranial hemorrhage, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, meningitis/encephalitis, hepatic encephalopathy, drug intoxication (valproic acid, asparaginase, 5-fluorouracil), Reye syndrome, organic acidurias, fatty acid oxidation defects
column8: Plasma ammonia greater than 100 micromoles per liter in neonates or greater than 50 micromoles per liter in older patients. Plasma amino acids, urine orotic acid, liver function tests, blood gas (respiratory alkalosis). Genetic testing for urea cycle disorders if indicated
column9: Immediate: stop protein intake, provide high-calorie glucose infusion to prevent catabolism. Hemodialysis for severe elevations (greater than 3-4 times upper limit of normal). Nitrogen scavengers: sodium benzoate, sodium phenylbutyrate. Arginine or citrulline supplementation. Treat underlying cause. Liver transplantation for refractory cases

column2: Headache, nausea, vomiting, altered consciousness; Cushing triad in severe cases
column3: Disruption of volume equilibrium between brain tissue, blood, and cerebrospinal fluid; exceeds compensatory mechanisms when intracranial volume increases
column4: Traumatic brain injury most common cause; also space-occupying lesions, hydrocephalus, cerebral edema
column5: Headache worse with lying flat or Valsalva, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, papilledema, sixth nerve palsy, Cushing triad (hypertension, bradycardia, irregular respirations) in severe cases
column6: Acute (hours) in trauma or hemorrhage; subacute to chronic (days to weeks) in tumors or idiopathic intracranial hypertension
column7: Mass lesions, hydrocephalus, cerebral edema, idiopathic intracranial hypertension, venous sinus thrombosis, meningitis
column8: CT or MRI brain showing mass effect, midline shift, or effacement of cisterns; intracranial pressure monitoring with threshold greater than 20-22 mm Hg pathologic; lumbar puncture contraindicated if mass effect present
column9: Elevate head of bed 30 degrees, maintain cerebral perfusion pressure, osmotic therapy with mannitol or hypertonic saline, hyperventilation for acute herniation, external ventricular drainage, surgical decompression for refractory cases

column2: Infant with rapidly increasing head circumference, bulging fontanelle, and "setting sun" eyes (downward gaze deviation)
column3: Impaired cerebrospinal fluid circulation due to congenital malformations (aqueductal stenosis, Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker malformation), intraventricular hemorrhage from prematurity, or infection; leads to ventricular enlargement and elevated intracranial pressure
column4: Most common cause in United States is intraventricular hemorrhage associated with prematurity; globally, infection is most common; approximately 400,000 cases worldwide annually
column5: Head circumference enlarging faster than expected, bulging anterior fontanelle, widely separated cranial sutures, downward deviated gaze (setting sun sign), irritability, lethargy, vomiting, apnea and bradycardia episodes, developmental regression
column6: Progressive over weeks to months; neonates rarely present in distress due to open fontanelles allowing decompression
column7: Benign external hydrocephalus (benign enlargement of subarachnoid space), macrocrania from other causes, brain tumors, subdural collections
column8: Prenatal: fetal ultrasound showing ventriculomegaly (atrial diameter greater than 10 millimeters); Postnatal: head ultrasound through open fontanelle, magnetic resonance imaging preferred over computed tomography to avoid radiation; serial head circumference measurements
column9: Temporizing: ventricular access device or ventriculosubgaleal shunt; Definitive: ventriculoperitoneal shunt or endoscopic third ventriculostomy with or without choroid plexus cauterization

column2: Sudden severe thunderclap headache, often described as "worst headache of life"; may have sentinel headache
column3: Rupture of arterial aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation causes bleeding into subarachnoid space or brain parenchyma; hypertension causes rupture of small penetrating arteries in deep structures
column4: Subarachnoid hemorrhage peak age 50-60 years; intracerebral hemorrhage more common in older adults with hypertension; men and women equally affected
column5: Thunderclap headache, loss of consciousness, neck stiffness, photophobia, focal neurologic deficits depending on location, seizures, nausea and vomiting
column6: Sudden onset over seconds to minutes; maximal intensity at onset
column7: Ischemic stroke, migraine, meningitis, cervical artery dissection, reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome
column8: Non-contrast CT head (sensitivity decreases over time for subarachnoid hemorrhage); CT angiography to identify aneurysm or vascular malformation; lumbar puncture if CT negative and high suspicion (xanthochromia); MRI for subacute presentations
column9: Subarachnoid hemorrhage: blood pressure control, nimodipine for vasospasm prevention, aneurysm securing via endovascular coiling or surgical clipping; intracerebral hemorrhage: blood pressure control (target systolic less than 140 mm Hg if no contraindication), reversal of coagulopathy, neurosurgical evaluation for evacuation

column2: Headache with papilledema in young woman; may have seizures or focal deficits; often associated with prothrombotic state
column3: Thrombosis of cerebral venous sinuses causes venous outflow obstruction leading to venous hypertension, vasogenic edema, and hemorrhagic venous infarction
column4: Young to middle-aged adults; female predominance (3:1); associated with pregnancy, oral contraceptives, prothrombotic conditions
column5: Headache (most common), seizures, focal neurologic deficits, papilledema, altered consciousness; hemorrhage often lobar or parasagittal with edema disproportionate to hemorrhage size
column6: Subacute onset over days to weeks; can be acute in fulminant cases
column7: Arterial intracerebral hemorrhage, ischemic stroke with hemorrhagic transformation, brain tumor, abscess
column8: MRI with MR venography or CT with CT venography showing filling defect in venous sinus; non-contrast CT may show hyperdense sinus (cord sign) or hemorrhage with surrounding edema; D-dimer often elevated
column9: Anticoagulation with heparin even in presence of hemorrhage (unless contraindicated); treat underlying prothrombotic condition; endovascular thrombolysis or thrombectomy for severe cases; manage intracranial pressure; treat seizures

column2: Elderly patient (over 55 years) with lobar hemorrhage, history of cognitive decline, and "amyloid spells" (transient focal neurological episodes)
column3: Beta-amyloid protein deposition in cortical and leptomeningeal vessel walls causes vessel weakening and rupture; associated with apolipoprotein E epsilon 2 and epsilon 4 alleles
column4: Second most common cause of spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage in elderly; predominantly affects patients over 55 years; accounts for 10 to 20 percent of all intracerebral hemorrhages
column5: Lobar intracerebral hemorrhage, cognitive impairment or dementia, transient focal neurological episodes (amyloid spells), convexity subarachnoid hemorrhage; symptoms depend on hemorrhage location
column6: Acute onset of hemorrhage; progressive cognitive decline over months to years; high risk of recurrent hemorrhage (approximately 7.5 percent per year, up to 26 percent per year with extensive cortical superficial siderosis)
column7: Hypertensive hemorrhage, hemorrhagic transformation of ischemic stroke, tumor, vascular malformation, anticoagulation-related hemorrhage
column8: MRI with gradient echo or susceptibility weighted imaging showing strictly lobar hemorrhagic lesions (intracerebral hemorrhage, cerebral microbleeds, cortical superficial siderosis); Boston Criteria version 2.0 for diagnosis; absence of deep hemorrhagic lesions; may show severe perivascular spaces in centrum semiovale or multispot white matter hyperintensities
column9: Acute blood pressure control; avoidance of anticoagulation and antiplatelet therapy when possible; strict blood pressure control for secondary prevention; fall precautions; cognitive assessment and support; admission to stroke unit

column2: Sudden onset severe headache with focal neurological deficits in patient with chronic hypertension; "worst headache of my life"
column3: Chronic hypertension causes lipohyalinosis and fibrinoid necrosis of small penetrating arteries, leading to vessel rupture in deep brain structures
column4: Most common cause of spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage; accounts for approximately 50 percent of cases; predominantly affects middle-aged and elderly patients with poorly controlled hypertension
column5: Sudden onset headache, nausea, vomiting, decreased level of consciousness, focal neurological deficits depending on location (hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, aphasia); may have signs of chronic hypertension (left ventricular hypertrophy, chronic kidney disease, hypertensive retinopathy)
column6: Acute onset with symptoms developing over minutes to hours; risk of hematoma expansion highest in first few hours; approximately 25 percent deteriorate in emergency department
column7: Cerebral amyloid angiopathy, hemorrhagic transformation of ischemic stroke, vascular malformation, tumor, coagulopathy, venous sinus thrombosis, reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome
column8: Noncontrast CT shows hyperdense lesion in basal ganglia, thalamus, pons, or cerebellum; CT angiography to assess for spot sign (predictor of expansion) and exclude vascular malformation; MRI gradient echo or susceptibility weighted imaging shows microbleeds preferentially in basal ganglia, pons, cerebellum
column9: Acute blood pressure control (target systolic blood pressure 140 mmHg or less if presenting systolic blood pressure 150 to 220 mmHg); reversal of coagulopathy if present; admission to stroke unit or neurointensive care unit; intracranial pressure management if needed; surgical evacuation considered for cerebellar hemorrhages with neurological deterioration or brainstem compression

column2: Sudden onset focal neurological deficit: hemiparesis, facial droop, dysarthria, aphasia, visual field defect; "time is brain"
column3: Acute arterial occlusion causing focal brain infarction due to thrombosis, embolism, or hypoperfusion. Ischemic cascade leads to neuronal death within minutes to hours
column4: 87% of all strokes in the United States. More than 700,000 strokes annually. Third leading cause of death. Risk factors: hypertension, diabetes, atrial fibrillation, smoking, hyperlipidemia
column5: Hemiparesis, dysarthria, sensory deficits, aphasia, visual deficits, facial droop, ataxia, altered mental status. Symptoms depend on vascular territory affected
column6: Acute onset (seconds to minutes). Symptoms maximal at onset. Therapeutic window: intravenous tissue plasminogen activator within 4.5 hours, mechanical thrombectomy within 24 hours
column7: Hemorrhagic stroke, transient ischemic attack, hypoglycemia, seizure with postictal state, migraine with aura, metabolic disturbances, encephalopathy, functional disorder, brain tumor
column8: Noncontrast computed tomography brain (excludes hemorrhage). Magnetic resonance imaging with diffusion-weighted imaging (detects infarction within minutes). National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale for severity. Glucose testing. Vascular imaging (computed tomography angiography or magnetic resonance angiography) for large vessel occlusion. Electrocardiogram, telemetry, echocardiography for etiology
column9: Intravenous tissue plasminogen activator if within 4.5 hours and eligible. Mechanical thrombectomy for large vessel occlusion within 24 hours. Aspirin 325 milligrams within 24-48 hours if not receiving thrombolysis. Blood pressure management (avoid lowering unless greater than 220/120 millimeters of mercury). Admit to stroke unit. Supportive care: oxygen, fever control, glucose control, deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis, dysphagia screening

column2: Sudden maximal deficit at onset with cortical signs in patient with atrial fibrillation or recent myocardial infarction; multiple vascular territories involved
column3: Embolus from cardiac source (atrial fibrillation, left ventricular thrombus, valvular disease, patent foramen ovale, atrial myxoma) travels to cerebral circulation causing arterial occlusion; emboli may fragment and migrate distally
column4: Accounts for approximately 25 percent of ischemic strokes globally; associated with higher morbidity and mortality compared to other stroke subtypes; prevalence increases with age due to atrial fibrillation
column5: Sudden onset maximal deficit, cortical signs (aphasia, neglect, hemianopia), hemiparesis, decreased consciousness if large territory; hemorrhagic transformation more common; may have evidence of systemic embolization; infarcts in multiple vascular territories suggest cardioembolic source
column6: Acute onset with symptoms maximal at onset; may have early improvement due to clot fragmentation and distal migration; high early recurrence risk without anticoagulation (up to 12 percent in first 2 weeks with atrial fibrillation)
column7: Large vessel atherosclerotic stroke, small vessel stroke, hemorrhagic stroke, aortic arch atheroma, paradoxical embolism, stroke mimic
column8: Noncontrast CT or MRI with diffusion weighted imaging shows cortical or territorial infarct; multiple infarcts in different vascular territories highly suggestive; CT angiography or MR angiography; transthoracic or transesophageal echocardiography; prolonged cardiac monitoring (minimum 24 hours, ideally 30 days) for atrial fibrillation
column9: Intravenous alteplase within 4.5 hours if eligible; endovascular thrombectomy for large vessel occlusion; oral anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation (direct oral anticoagulants preferred over warfarin); anticoagulation for left ventricular thrombus; patent foramen ovale closure in select patients with cryptogenic stroke; risk factor modification

column2: Sudden onset cortical signs (aphasia, neglect, gaze deviation) in patient with vascular risk factors; "wake up stroke"
column3: Atherosclerotic plaque rupture or artery-to-artery thromboembolism from internal carotid artery or major intracranial arteries (middle cerebral artery M1 segment, basilar artery) causing occlusion; may also result from in situ thrombosis on stenotic lesion
column4: Accounts for approximately 15 to 20 percent of ischemic strokes; more common in patients with hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, smoking history; higher prevalence in certain ethnic groups with intracranial atherosclerosis
column5: Cortical dysfunction (aphasia, neglect, hemianopia), hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, gaze deviation, decreased level of consciousness if large territory involved; symptoms depend on vascular territory; may have preceding transient ischemic attacks in same territory
column6: Acute onset over minutes; symptoms maximal at onset or stuttering progression; may present as wake-up stroke; risk of malignant edema with large middle cerebral artery infarction peaks at 2 to 5 days
column7: Cardioembolic stroke, small vessel stroke, hemorrhagic stroke, stroke mimic (seizure, migraine, metabolic), intracranial mass, cerebral venous thrombosis
column8: Noncontrast CT or MRI with diffusion weighted imaging shows wedge-shaped territorial infarct; CT angiography or MR angiography shows large vessel occlusion or greater than 50 percent stenosis; carotid Doppler ultrasonography for extracranial disease; cardiac monitoring to exclude atrial fibrillation
column9: Intravenous alteplase within 4.5 hours if eligible; endovascular thrombectomy within 24 hours for large vessel occlusion with favorable imaging; antiplatelet therapy (aspirin, clopidogrel, or ticagrelor); carotid endarterectomy or stenting for symptomatic high-grade stenosis; intensive risk factor modification

column2: Pure motor hemiparesis, pure sensory stroke, or ataxic hemiparesis in patient with hypertension and diabetes; no cortical signs
column3: Lipohyalinosis and fibrinoid necrosis of small penetrating arteries (lenticulostriate arteries, thalamoperforators, pontine perforators) due to chronic hypertension and diabetes; occlusion of small deep perforating arterioles
column4: Accounts for 20 to 30 percent of ischemic strokes; strongly associated with chronic hypertension and diabetes; leading cause of vascular dementia and vascular cognitive impairment
column5: Classic lacunar syndromes: pure motor hemiparesis, pure sensory stroke, ataxic hemiparesis, dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome, sensorimotor stroke; absence of cortical signs (no aphasia, neglect, hemianopia, or decreased consciousness)
column6: Acute onset over minutes to hours; may have stuttering progression; recurrence risk 4 to 11 percent per year; progressive cognitive decline over years with recurrent events
column7: Large vessel stroke with small infarct, cardioembolic stroke, hemorrhagic stroke, demyelinating disease, small hemorrhage, metabolic disorder
column8: MRI with diffusion weighted imaging shows subcortical infarct less than 15 millimeters diameter in basal ganglia, internal capsule, thalamus, pons, or corona radiata; gradient echo or susceptibility weighted imaging may show cerebral microbleeds; vascular imaging and cardiac workup to exclude other causes
column9: Antiplatelet therapy with single agent (aspirin, clopidogrel, or ticagrelor); dual antiplatelet therapy not recommended due to increased bleeding without benefit; intensive blood pressure control; diabetes management; statin therapy; lifestyle modifications

column2: Middle-aged smoker with proximal leg weakness that improves with exercise, dry mouth, and diminished reflexes; "weakness that gets better with use, think small cell lung cancer"
column3: Autoimmune presynaptic disorder with antibodies against P/Q-type voltage-gated calcium channels on presynaptic nerve terminals; reduces acetylcholine vesicle release probability; 50 to 60 percent paraneoplastic (most commonly small cell lung cancer), remainder non-tumor autoimmune
column4: Rare; incidence less than 1 per million per year; prevalence approximately 3 per million; male predominance; mean age of onset 60 years for small cell lung cancer-associated, 35 years for non-tumor
column5: Proximal leg weakness (initial symptom in 80 percent) spreading caudal-to-cranial; autonomic dysfunction (dry mouth in 57 percent, erectile dysfunction in 53 percent, constipation); diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes that may return after exercise; cranial nerve involvement less common than myasthenia gravis; ocular symptoms rare
column6: Progressive over weeks to months; small cell lung cancer-associated progresses more rapidly than non-tumor form
column7: Myasthenia gravis, polymyositis, inclusion body myositis, mitochondrial myopathy, Guillain-Barré syndrome, botulism
column8: Electromyography: small compound muscle action potentials at rest with greater than 100 percent increment after 10 seconds of maximal voluntary contraction or high-frequency (20 to 50 hertz) repetitive nerve stimulation; low-frequency (2 to 5 hertz) stimulation shows decrement; anti-voltage-gated calcium channel antibodies positive in 85 to 90 percent; computed tomography chest for small cell lung cancer screening
column9: Symptomatic: amifampridine (3,4-diaminopyridine) first-line to increase acetylcholine release; Immunotherapy: prednisone plus azathioprine, intravenous immunoglobulin, or plasma exchange for persistent symptoms; Oncologic: treat underlying small cell lung cancer if present (takes priority); Non-tumor form has normal life expectancy

column2: Elderly patient with chronic hypertension presenting with pure motor hemiparesis or other lacunar syndrome; no cortical signs
column3: Chronic hypertension causes plasma protein deposition and fibrinoid necrosis in walls of small penetrating arterioles (50 to 200 micrometers diameter); leads to vessel wall thickening, luminal narrowing, and eventual occlusion; affects lenticulostriate arteries, thalamoperforators, and pontine perforators
column4: Most common pathological finding in lacunar infarction; strongly associated with chronic poorly controlled hypertension and diabetes; prevalence increases with age; more common in patients with chronic kidney disease
column5: Lacunar syndromes: pure motor hemiparesis, pure sensory stroke, ataxic hemiparesis, dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome; absence of cortical signs; may be asymptomatic with chronic white matter changes and cognitive decline
column6: Develops over years to decades of chronic hypertension; acute occlusion causes lacunar infarct with symptoms over minutes to hours; chronic changes contribute to vascular dementia over years
column7: Microatheroma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, other small vessel diseases, demyelinating disease, small hemorrhage
column8: MRI with diffusion weighted imaging shows small subcortical infarct less than 15 millimeters; fluid attenuated inversion recovery shows white matter hyperintensities; gradient echo shows microbleeds in deep structures; pathological diagnosis on autopsy or biopsy
column9: Intensive blood pressure control (target less than 130 over 80 millimeters mercury); antiplatelet therapy; statin therapy; diabetes management; lifestyle modifications; treatment of acute lacunar stroke follows standard protocols

column2: Fever, headache, neck stiffness (classic triad); Kernig and Brudzinski signs positive; petechial rash in meningococcal disease
column3: Inflammation of meninges from bacterial, viral, or fungal infection; bacterial causes include Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, Listeria monocytogenes; viral causes include enteroviruses and herpes simplex virus
column4: Bacterial meningitis incidence 0.4-0.8 per 100,000 adults in high-income countries; Streptococcus pneumoniae causes 72% of bacterial cases in adults over 16 years; viral meningitis more common overall
column5: Fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, photophobia, altered mental status, nausea and vomiting; may have seizures or focal neurologic deficits
column6: Acute onset over hours to days; bacterial progresses more rapidly than viral
column7: Encephalitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, brain abscess, migraine, viral syndrome
column8: Lumbar puncture with cerebrospinal fluid analysis showing elevated white blood cells, elevated protein, decreased glucose in bacterial; Gram stain and culture; polymerase chain reaction for viral pathogens; blood cultures
column9: Empiric antibiotics immediately (ceftriaxone plus vancomycin; add ampicillin if Listeria suspected); dexamethasone before or with first antibiotic dose; acyclovir if viral encephalitis not excluded; duration typically 10-14 days for bacterial

column2: Patient with vascular risk factors presenting with lacunar syndrome; small atherosclerotic plaque at origin of penetrating artery
