column3: Atherosclerotic plaque formation at ostium or proximal portion of small penetrating arterioles; plaque rupture or in situ thrombosis causes occlusion of penetrating vessel; represents branch atheromatous disease; distinct from lipohyalinosis but both cause lacunar infarction
column4: Accounts for minority of lacunar infarcts (estimated 15 to 25 percent); associated with traditional atherosclerotic risk factors (hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, smoking); may be more common in certain ethnic populations
column5: Lacunar syndromes identical to lipohyalinosis: pure motor hemiparesis, pure sensory stroke, ataxic hemiparesis, dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome; absence of cortical signs; symptoms depend on location of affected penetrating artery
column6: Acute onset over minutes to hours; may have stuttering progression as plaque extends into penetrating vessel; recurrence risk similar to other atherosclerotic disease
column7: Lipohyalinosis, cardioembolic stroke with small infarct, large vessel atherosclerosis with small territorial infarct, small hemorrhage, demyelinating disease
column8: MRI with diffusion weighted imaging shows subcortical infarct less than 15 millimeters; high-resolution MRI may show parent artery atherosclerotic plaque; vascular imaging to assess for large vessel disease; cardiac workup to exclude cardioembolic source
column9: Antiplatelet therapy (aspirin, clopidogrel, or ticagrelor); intensive statin therapy; blood pressure control; diabetes management; smoking cessation; lifestyle modifications

column2: Newborn or infant with head circumference more than 2 standard deviations below mean for age and gender; may have developmental delays, seizures; "small head, check for causes"
column3: Multiple etiologies: primary (genetic mutations affecting brain development) or secondary (intrauterine infections, toxins, hypoxic-ischemic injury, malnutrition); results in reduced brain growth and neuronal proliferation
column4: 2.3% of children by definition (head circumference less than minus 2 standard deviations); severe microcephaly (less than minus 3 standard deviations) in 0.1%; varies by etiology and population
column5: Small head circumference (less than minus 2 standard deviations), developmental delay, intellectual disability, seizures, motor abnormalities; may have associated dysmorphic features depending on etiology; normal cognition possible in familial microcephaly
column6: Congenital microcephaly present at birth; postnatal microcephaly develops after birth due to acquired insults; progressive if underlying cause not addressed
column7: Craniosynostosis, constitutional microcephaly, intrauterine growth restriction, chromosomal disorders, congenital infections, metabolic disorders
column8: Accurate head circumference measurement using standardized growth charts; brain MRI to evaluate brain structure and classify type; genetic testing if syndromic features; metabolic workup; TORCH titers if congenital infection suspected
column9: Treat underlying cause if identified; supportive care including developmental therapies, seizure management, nutritional support; genetic counseling; early intervention services; monitor for complications

column2: Ipsilateral sixth and seventh nerve palsies with contralateral hemiparesis; "ventral pons crossed syndrome"
column3: Ventral pontine lesion affecting abducens nerve fascicles, facial nerve fascicles, and corticospinal tract; most commonly due to pontine infarction from basilar artery perforating branches; also demyelination, tumor, hemorrhage
column4: Rare; typically affects adults with vascular risk factors; less common than other brainstem syndromes
column5: Ipsilateral: lateral rectus palsy (inability to abduct eye), peripheral facial palsy (facial weakness including forehead); Contralateral: hemiparesis or hemiplegia
column6: Acute onset with vascular causes (minutes to hours); subacute with demyelinating or mass lesions
column7: Foville syndrome (includes gaze palsy), other pontine strokes, multiple sclerosis, pontine glioma, basilar artery thrombosis
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging shows ventral pontine lesion; magnetic resonance angiography to evaluate basilar artery and branches; diffusion-weighted imaging for acute infarction
column9: Acute stroke: thrombolysis or thrombectomy if eligible; secondary prevention with antiplatelet or anticoagulation; physical therapy; eye patching for diplopia

column2: Young woman with optic neuritis, internuclear ophthalmoplegia, or transverse myelitis with symptoms separated in time and space; "Charcot triad: nystagmus, intention tremor, scanning speech"
column3: Autoimmune demyelination of central nervous system white matter; T cell-mediated inflammation causes oligodendrocyte damage and myelin loss; formation of demyelinating plaques (sclerosis) disseminated in time and space; axonal damage occurs with disease progression
column4: Most common nontraumatic cause of neurologic disability in young adults; prevalence 200 per 100,000 in United States; female to male ratio 3 to 1; peak onset 20 to 40 years; higher prevalence at northern latitudes
column5: Optic neuritis (painful vision loss, afferent pupillary defect), internuclear ophthalmoplegia, transverse myelitis, Lhermitte sign (electric shock sensation with neck flexion), sensory symptoms, weakness, ataxia, bladder dysfunction, fatigue, heat sensitivity (Uhthoff phenomenon), cognitive impairment
column6: Relapsing-remitting (85 percent): discrete attacks with recovery; Secondary progressive: gradual worsening after relapsing-remitting phase; Primary progressive (15 percent): gradual progression from onset
column7: Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder, acute disseminated encephalomyelitis, neurosyphilis, Lyme disease, sarcoidosis, systemic lupus erythematosus, vitamin B12 deficiency, cerebrovascular disease
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging brain and spine showing periventricular, juxtacortical, infratentorial, or spinal cord lesions (Dawson fingers); cerebrospinal fluid with oligoclonal bands, elevated immunoglobulin G index; McDonald criteria require dissemination in space and time; visual evoked potentials
column9: Acute relapse: high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone, plasma exchange for severe relapses; Disease-modifying therapies: first-line (interferon beta, glatiramer acetate, teriflunomide, dimethyl fumarate), high-efficacy (natalizumab, ocrelizumab, alemtuzumab, cladribine); symptomatic management

column2: Ptosis and diplopia that worsen with sustained activity; "ice pack test" improves ptosis
column3: Autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptor, muscle-specific kinase, or other postsynaptic proteins impair neuromuscular transmission
column4: Affects all ages; female predominance in early onset (less than 50 years); associated with thymic abnormalities
column5: Fluctuating muscle weakness worsening with activity; ocular symptoms (ptosis, diplopia); bulbar weakness (dysphagia, dysarthria); respiratory muscle involvement in crisis
column6: Chronic progressive with fluctuations; myasthenic crisis can develop acutely
column7: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, botulism, oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy, mitochondrial myopathy, brainstem lesions
column8: Acetylcholine receptor or muscle-specific kinase antibodies; repetitive nerve stimulation showing decremental response; single-fiber electromyography; edrophonium test; chest imaging for thymoma
column9: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (pyridostigmine); immunosuppression (azathioprine, corticosteroids); thymectomy in selected cases; intravenous immunoglobulin or plasma exchange for exacerbations; eculizumab for refractory cases

column2: Seizures in patient from endemic area (Latin America, sub-Saharan Africa, Asia); ring-enhancing lesions with scolex (dot sign) on imaging
column3: Infection of central nervous system with larval cysts of Taenia solium acquired by ingestion of ova from contaminated food or water; cysts can be in brain parenchyma, ventricles, or subarachnoid space
column4: Major cause of seizures worldwide; linked to 29% of seizure cases in endemic areas; over 2000 cases per year in United States; endemic in Latin America, sub-Saharan Africa, parts of Asia
column5: Seizures (most common in parenchymal disease), headache, increased intracranial pressure, focal neurologic deficits, hydrocephalus; symptoms vary by cyst location and stage
column6: Chronic course over months to years; symptoms depend on cyst degeneration and host inflammatory response
column7: Brain abscess, brain tumor, tuberculoma, toxoplasmosis, metastases
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging or computed tomography showing cystic lesions with or without scolex; enzyme-linked immunotransfer blot serology for confirmation; cerebrospinal fluid analysis if needed
column9: Antiparasitic therapy with albendazole (15 mg per kg per day) or praziquantel for viable parenchymal cysts; corticosteroids to reduce inflammation; antiepileptics for seizure control; neurosurgery for ventricular or subarachnoid disease; duration typically 10-14 days

column2: Elderly patient with "wet, wobbly, and wacky" triad: gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and cognitive impairment
column3: Impaired cerebrospinal fluid dynamics with abnormal intracranial pressure waveforms and compliance despite normal or minimally elevated cerebrospinal fluid pressure on lumbar puncture; communicating hydrocephalus without ventricular obstruction
column4: Typically occurs in persons older than 60 years; idiopathic form more common than secondary form
column5: Gait: wide-based, shuffling, short steps, difficulty initiating walking, freezing, falls with turns, slow velocity (less than 1 meter per second); Urinary: urgency, frequency, difficulty inhibiting bladder emptying; Cognitive: nonamnestic memory impairment (benefits from cues), slowed processing speed, impaired executive function, apathy; no papilledema or severe headaches
column6: Insidious onset over months to years; progressive without treatment
column7: Parkinson disease, Alzheimer dementia, Lewy body dementia, vascular cognitive impairment, spinal stenosis, peripheral neuropathy, asymptomatic ventriculomegaly, medication side effects
column8: Brain magnetic resonance imaging or computed tomography showing ventriculomegaly with effacement of sulci at vertex; prognostic testing: high-volume lumbar puncture (30 to 50 milliliters cerebrospinal fluid removal) with gait assessment, or external lumbar drainage; neuropsychological testing showing frontal-subcortical pattern
column9: Ventriculoperitoneal shunt or ventriculoatrial shunt placement; approximately 63 percent have complete triad, but 96 percent have gait difficulty

column2: Infant with rapidly increasing head circumference and bulging fontanelle; older child with headache, vomiting, and sixth nerve palsy causing diplopia
column3: Obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid flow within ventricular system or at exit foramina; causes include aqueductal stenosis, posterior fossa tumors, colloid cysts, or congenital malformations; elevated intracranial pressure results
column4: Common in pediatric population; approximately 400,000 cases of infantile and childhood hydrocephalus occur worldwide annually; etiologies include aqueductal stenosis, myelomeningocele, post-hemorrhagic hydrocephalus in premature infants
column5: Infants: rapidly increasing head circumference crossing percentiles, bulging anterior fontanelle, splaying of cranial sutures, irritability, vomiting, upgaze palsy; older children and adults: headache, nausea, vomiting, papilledema, sixth nerve palsy, altered mental status
column6: Acute to subacute onset over days to weeks depending on degree of obstruction; can present as acute emergency with rapid deterioration
column7: Communicating hydrocephalus, benign external hydrocephalus in infants, pseudotumor cerebri, brain tumor without hydrocephalus, subdural hematoma
column8: Cranial ultrasound in infants with open fontanelle; magnetic resonance imaging preferred over computed tomography to avoid radiation and identify obstruction site; cine magnetic resonance imaging cerebrospinal fluid flow studies can identify obstruction; avoid lumbar puncture due to herniation risk
column9: Endoscopic third ventriculostomy for aqueductal stenosis and other obstructive causes when appropriate; ventriculoperitoneal shunt or ventriculoatrial shunt; temporizing ventricular access device or ventriculo-subgaleal shunt in neonates; treat underlying cause such as tumor resection

column2: Cholinergic crisis with salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastrointestinal distress, emesis, miosis, bronchorrhea, bronchospasm, bradycardia, muscle fasciculations, weakness; "SLUDGE and killer Bs" or "DUMBELS"; exposure to pesticides or nerve agents
column3: Irreversible inhibition of acetylcholinesterase at neural synapses; accumulation of acetylcholine causes overstimulation of muscarinic receptors (SLUDGE symptoms), nicotinic receptors (muscle fasciculations, weakness, paralysis, sympathetic effects), and central nervous system receptors (confusion, seizures, coma, respiratory depression); respiratory failure from central apnea, bronchospasm, secretions, muscle paralysis
column4: Common cause of poisoning worldwide; intentional self-harm, occupational exposure, accidental exposure, chemical warfare; affects all ages; higher mortality in developing countries; intermediate syndrome develops 1-4 days after exposure in 20-68% of cases; delayed neuropathy may occur weeks later
column5: Muscarinic: salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastrointestinal distress, emesis, miosis, bronchorrhea, bronchospasm, bradycardia; Nicotinic: muscle fasciculations, weakness, paralysis, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis; Central nervous system: confusion, agitation, seizures, coma, respiratory depression; garlic or petroleum odor may be present
column6: Acute: symptoms within 30-90 minutes of ingestion, seconds to minutes with inhalation; may persist for days; Intermediate syndrome: muscle weakness and respiratory failure 1-4 days after exposure; Delayed neuropathy: peripheral neuropathy weeks to months after exposure
column7: Carbamate poisoning (similar but shorter duration), nicotine toxicity, muscarinic mushroom poisoning, nerve agent exposure, other causes of cholinergic crisis or seizures
column8: Low red blood cell cholinesterase and serum cholinesterase levels (may not be immediately available); clinical diagnosis based on history and toxidrome; metabolic acidosis, hyperlactatemia on laboratory studies; response to atropine confirms diagnosis
column9: Decontamination: remove clothing, wash skin with soap and water (providers wear personal protective equipment); Atropine: 1-3 milligrams intravenous, double dose every 5 minutes until atropinization (clear lungs, heart rate greater than 80, systolic blood pressure greater than 80), then continuous infusion; Pralidoxime: 1-2 grams intravenous over 30 minutes, then 0.5-1 gram per hour infusion; Benzodiazepines for seizures; early intubation for respiratory failure; avoid succinylcholine (prolonged paralysis)

column2: Bilateral optic disc swelling with preserved central vision; transient visual obscurations; headache worse in morning
column3: Elevated intracranial pressure transmitted through optic nerve sheath causes axoplasmic flow stasis and optic disc edema
column4: Most common in idiopathic intracranial hypertension; affects women of childbearing age with obesity more frequently
column5: Headache, transient visual obscurations, peripheral visual field loss, diplopia from sixth nerve palsy, pulsatile tinnitus; central acuity preserved until late
column6: Progressive over days to weeks; vision loss gradual from periphery inward
column7: Pseudopapilledema from optic disc drusen, optic neuritis, central retinal vein occlusion, hypertensive retinopathy, infiltrative optic neuropathy
column8: Fundoscopy showing disc elevation with blurred margins and venous engorgement; optical coherence tomography for retinal nerve fiber layer thickness; brain MRI with venography; lumbar puncture with opening pressure measurement
column9: Treat underlying cause; for idiopathic intracranial hypertension: weight loss and acetazolamide first-line; surgical options include optic nerve sheath fenestration or cerebrospinal fluid shunting for refractory cases

column2: Young patient with stroke and deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism; may have history of prolonged immobilization or Valsalva maneuver
column3: Venous thrombus or right heart thrombus crosses from right-sided to left-sided circulation through intracardiac shunt (patent foramen ovale most common, atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect) or pulmonary arteriovenous malformation; requires right atrial pressure exceeding left atrial pressure to open shunt; embolus enters systemic arterial circulation causing end-organ ischemia
column4: Patent foramen ovale present in 25 to 30 percent of general population; paradoxical embolism accounts for small percentage of cryptogenic strokes, especially in younger patients; cerebrum most commonly affected organ (stroke), followed by peripheral arterial occlusion, mesenteric ischemia, rarely myocardial infarction
column5: Acute stroke (most common presentation), peripheral arterial occlusion with cold pulseless extremity, myocardial infarction, mesenteric ischemia, renal infarction; may have concurrent symptoms of pulmonary embolism (chest pain, dyspnea) or deep vein thrombosis (leg swelling, pain)
column6: Acute onset over minutes; timing often coincides with Valsalva maneuver, coughing, or straining that increases right atrial pressure; may occur during acute pulmonary embolism when right atrial pressure acutely elevated
column7: Cardioembolic stroke from atrial fibrillation, large vessel atherosclerotic stroke, small vessel stroke, aortic arch atheroma, infective endocarditis, atrial myxoma
column8: Imaging shows arterial embolism (brain MRI, CT angiography of affected vascular bed); transesophageal echocardiography with bubble study to detect patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect; venous Doppler ultrasonography for deep vein thrombosis; CT pulmonary angiography for pulmonary embolism; cardiac monitoring to exclude atrial fibrillation
column9: Anticoagulation for venous thromboembolism (minimum 3 to 6 months); patent foramen ovale closure in select patients with recurrent cryptogenic stroke and high-risk features; antiplatelet therapy if anticoagulation contraindicated; treatment of underlying venous thromboembolism risk factors

column2: Elderly patient with resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and shuffling gait; "pill-rolling tremor at rest that improves with movement"
column3: Progressive degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in substantia nigra pars compacta; intracellular accumulation of alpha-synuclein (Lewy bodies); leads to dopamine depletion in striatum and motor circuit dysfunction
column4: Second most common neurodegenerative disease; prevalence 1 to 2 per 1000 in general population, 1 percent in those over 60 years; male to female ratio approximately 1.5 to 1
column5: Motor: resting tremor (4 to 6 hertz, asymmetric), bradykinesia, rigidity (cogwheel or lead-pipe), postural instability, shuffling gait, reduced arm swing, masked facies, micrographia; Nonmotor: hyposmia, constipation, rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder, depression, cognitive impairment
column6: Insidious onset; progressive over years to decades; symptoms typically begin unilaterally then become bilateral; motor symptoms appear after 50 to 80 percent of dopaminergic neurons lost
column7: Essential tremor, drug-induced parkinsonism, vascular parkinsonism, progressive supranuclear palsy, multiple system atrophy, corticobasal degeneration, Lewy body dementia
column8: Clinical diagnosis based on United Kingdom Parkinson Disease Society Brain Bank criteria; requires bradykinesia plus rigidity or resting tremor; supportive: asymmetric onset, excellent response to levodopa; dopamine transporter scan if diagnosis uncertain; magnetic resonance imaging to exclude structural lesions
column9: Levodopa-carbidopa (most effective, gold standard); dopamine agonists (pramipexole, ropinirole); monoamine oxidase B inhibitors (selegiline, rasagiline); catechol-O-methyltransferase inhibitors (entacapone); anticholinergics for tremor in younger patients; deep brain stimulation for advanced disease with motor fluctuations

column2: Newborn with small chin, tongue falling back, and respiratory distress in supine position
column3: Mandibular hypoplasia leads to posterior displacement of tongue (glossoptosis), which obstructs airway and may prevent palatal shelf fusion
column4: Incidence approximately 1 in 8,500 to 14,000 live births; can be isolated or part of syndrome
column5: Micrognathia, glossoptosis, airway obstruction with stridor, retractions, cyanosis; cleft palate (U-shaped) in majority; feeding difficulty, reflux, failure to thrive
column6: Congenital; airway obstruction most severe in first months of life, often improves with mandibular growth
column7: Treacher Collins Syndrome, Stickler syndrome, velocardiofacial syndrome, isolated micrognathia
column8: Clinical diagnosis based on triad; polysomnography to assess obstruction severity; genetic testing if syndromic features present; imaging to evaluate mandible and airway
column9: Conservative: prone positioning, nasopharyngeal airway, feeding support; Surgical: tongue-lip adhesion, mandibular distraction osteogenesis, tracheostomy for severe cases

column2: Loss of proprioception, vibration, and fine touch with preserved motor function and pain sensation; "can't tell where limbs are but can move them and feel pain"
column3: Injury to dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis and cuneatus) from posterior spinal artery ischemia, vitamin B12 deficiency, tabes dorsalis, or direct trauma; spinothalamic and corticospinal tracts spared
column4: Rarest incomplete spinal cord syndrome; more commonly due to non-traumatic causes (vitamin B12 deficiency, syphilis, multiple sclerosis) than trauma
column5: Loss of proprioception, vibration sense, two-point discrimination, and fine touch below lesion; motor function preserved; pain and temperature sensation preserved; sensory ataxia with positive Romberg sign
column6: Variable depending on etiology: acute with trauma or ischemia, subacute to chronic with metabolic or infectious causes
column7: Vitamin B12 deficiency, tabes dorsalis, multiple sclerosis, subacute combined degeneration, Friedreich ataxia, peripheral neuropathy
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging shows posterior column signal abnormality; vitamin B12 and methylmalonic acid levels; syphilis serology; copper levels; neurological examination
column9: Treat underlying cause: vitamin B12 supplementation, penicillin for neurosyphilis; Rehabilitation: physical therapy focusing on gait training and fall prevention; assistive devices

column2: Child or young adult with severe burning pain, redness, and warmth in feet or hands triggered by heat or exercise; relieved by cooling
column3: Autosomal dominant gain-of-function mutation in sodium voltage-gated channel alpha subunit 9 gene; encodes voltage-gated sodium channel expressed in dorsal root ganglia and sympathetic neurons; mutation causes hyperexcitability and lowered threshold for action potential firing in nociceptive neurons
column4: Rare; prevalence less than 1 per 100,000; primary (inherited) form typically presents in childhood or adolescence; equal gender distribution
column5: Episodic severe burning pain in distal extremities (feet more than hands); erythema, warmth, swelling of affected areas; triggered by warmth, exercise, standing, alcohol; relieved by cooling, elevation; patients may immerse feet in ice water; skin ulceration from excessive cooling
column6: Episodes last minutes to hours; frequency increases over time; may become continuous; symptoms worsen with age
column7: Secondary erythromelalgia (myeloproliferative disorders, autoimmune disease, medications), peripheral neuropathy, complex regional pain syndrome, Raynaud phenomenon, cellulitis
column8: Clinical diagnosis based on triad of erythema, warmth, and burning pain; genetic testing for sodium voltage-gated channel alpha subunit 9 mutations confirms primary form; skin biopsy shows reduced intraepidermal nerve fiber density; exclude secondary causes (complete blood count, inflammatory markers)
column9: Avoid triggers (heat, tight footwear); cooling measures with caution (avoid tissue damage); medications: gabapentin, carbamazepine, mexiletine (sodium channel blocker), topical lidocaine, tricyclic antidepressants; aspirin for secondary erythromelalgia due to thrombocythemia

column2: Sudden onset "worst headache of my life" (thunderclap headache) with or without loss of consciousness, neck stiffness, photophobia; "thunderclap equals subarachnoid until proven otherwise"
column3: Rupture of intracranial aneurysm (85 percent) or arteriovenous malformation; blood enters subarachnoid space between arachnoid and pia mater; causes meningeal irritation and increased intracranial pressure
column4: Peak incidence 40 to 60 years; risk factors include hypertension, smoking, family history, polycystic kidney disease; 3 percent of all strokes
column5: Sudden severe headache (thunderclap), loss of consciousness (26 to 53 percent), neck pain or stiffness, photophobia, nausea and vomiting, focal neurologic deficits, seizures, third nerve palsy with posterior communicating artery aneurysm
column6: Sudden onset over seconds; maximal intensity at onset; symptoms persist
column7: Migraine, tension headache, meningitis, cervical artery dissection, reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome, cerebral venous thrombosis, intracerebral hemorrhage
column8: Noncontrast computed tomography head (nearly 100 percent sensitive within 6 hours, 86 to 97 percent sensitive 6 to 72 hours); if computed tomography negative, lumbar puncture showing xanthochromia or red blood cells; computed tomography angiography or digital subtraction angiography to identify aneurysm
column9: Blood pressure control (systolic less than 140 millimeters mercury); nimodipine to prevent vasospasm; antiepileptic medication; neurosurgical or endovascular aneurysm repair (clipping or coiling); intensive care unit monitoring

column2: Elderly patient or patient on anticoagulation with history of minor head trauma (may be remote) presenting with headache, confusion, or focal deficits; "crescent-shaped bleed"
column3: Venous bleeding from tearing of bridging veins between cortex and venous sinuses due to rotational forces; blood accumulates between dura and arachnoid; crosses suture lines but not midline
column4: More common in elderly, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulation; associated with brain atrophy which stretches bridging veins
column5: Headache, confusion, altered mental status, focal neurologic deficits (hemiparesis), seizures; symptoms may be subtle in chronic subdural hematoma; acute subdural may present with rapid deterioration
column6: Acute (less than 3 days), subacute (3 to 21 days), or chronic (greater than 21 days); chronic may have insidious onset over weeks to months
column7: Epidural hematoma, subarachnoid hemorrhage, ischemic stroke, dementia, normal pressure hydrocephalus, brain tumor
column8: Noncontrast computed tomography head shows crescent-shaped (concave) hyperdense (acute) or hypodense (chronic) collection along brain surface; crosses suture lines but not midline
column9: Acute symptomatic: emergent neurosurgical evacuation; reverse coagulopathy; Chronic: surgical drainage for symptomatic or large hematomas; observation for small asymptomatic

column2: Patient with trismus (lockjaw), risus sardonicus (sardonic smile), opisthotonus (arched back) following penetrating wound; "rigid paralysis with muscle spasms"
column3: Clostridium tetani spores enter through wound; vegetative bacteria produce tetanospasmin toxin; toxin blocks inhibitory neurotransmitter release (gamma-aminobutyric acid, glycine) from Renshaw cells in spinal cord; causes uninhibited motor neuron firing and sustained muscle contraction
column4: Rare in developed countries due to vaccination; approximately 30 cases per year in United States; unvaccinated or inadequately vaccinated individuals; contaminated wounds (puncture wounds, burns, injection drug use)
column5: Trismus (lockjaw), risus sardonicus (facial muscle spasm causing grimace), dysphagia, neck stiffness, opisthotonus (severe back arching), generalized muscle rigidity and spasms triggered by stimuli; autonomic instability (tachycardia, hypertension, arrhythmias); patient remains alert and conscious; no sensory loss
column6: Incubation 3 to 21 days (average 8 days); shorter incubation associated with worse prognosis; generalized tetanus progresses over days; recovery over weeks to months
column7: Strychnine poisoning, neuroleptic malignant syndrome, serotonin syndrome, meningitis, encephalitis, dystonic reaction, hypocalcemic tetany, seizure disorder, rabies
column8: Clinical diagnosis; no laboratory test confirms tetanus; wound culture may grow Clostridium tetani but negative culture does not exclude diagnosis; spatula test (touching posterior pharynx causes jaw spasm, highly specific)
column9: Human tetanus immunoglobulin (3000 to 6000 units intramuscularly); metronidazole or penicillin G to eradicate bacteria; wound debridement; benzodiazepines for muscle spasms; neuromuscular blockade and mechanical ventilation for severe cases; magnesium sulfate for autonomic instability; tetanus toxoid vaccination (disease does not confer immunity)

column2: Sudden onset focal neurologic deficit lasting minutes with complete resolution; older patient with vascular risk factors
column3: Temporary focal cerebral ischemia without tissue infarction; caused by thromboembolism, atherosclerosis, or other vascular mechanisms with spontaneous reperfusion
column4: At least 240,000 cases annually in United States; 90-day stroke risk up to 17.8% with half occurring within 48 hours
column5: Unilateral weakness, sensory deficit, aphasia, dysarthria, visual field defect, or monocular blindness; symptoms typically last less than 1 hour; abrupt onset
column6: Symptoms resolve completely within 24 hours by traditional definition; tissue-based definition requires no infarction on diffusion-weighted imaging regardless of duration
column7: Ischemic stroke with infarction, seizure, migraine with aura, hypoglycemia, peripheral vertigo, syncope
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging with diffusion-weighted imaging to exclude infarction; vascular imaging of carotid and intracranial vessels; electrocardiogram and cardiac monitoring; risk stratification with ABCD2 score
column9: Dual antiplatelet therapy for 21 days if high risk; single antiplatelet long-term; statin therapy; blood pressure control; carotid revascularization if severe stenosis; address cardioembolic sources

column2: Newborn with "bird-like facies," downward slanting eyes, and absent cheekbones
column3: Abnormal differentiation of first and second pharyngeal arches during fetal development; mutations in TCOF1, POLR1D, POLR1C, or POLR1B genes affecting ribosomal biogenesis
column4: 1 in 50,000 live births; autosomal dominant inheritance with variable penetrance and incomplete penetrance possible
column5: Malar and mandibular hypoplasia, micrognathia, downward slanting palpebral fissures, eyelid coloboma of lower lids, microtia with conductive hearing loss, cleft palate (occasional), choanal atresia or stenosis (rare)
column6: Congenital; features present at birth with normal intelligence typically preserved
column7: Pierre Robin Sequence, Nager syndrome, Goldenhar syndrome, hemifacial microsomia
column8: Clinical diagnosis confirmed by genetic testing for TCOF1, POLR1D, POLR1C, POLR1B mutations; imaging for airway and skeletal assessment
column9: Multidisciplinary management including airway support if needed, hearing aids or bone-anchored hearing devices, reconstructive craniofacial surgery, speech therapy

column2: Extracellular fluid accumulation with finger-like projections into white matter; seen with brain tumors, abscesses, or hypertensive crisis
column3: Blood-brain barrier breakdown allows protein-rich fluid extravasation into extracellular space; mediated by vascular endothelial growth factor in tumors; tight junction opening or immature vessel sprouting
column4: Common with brain tumors, infections, trauma, posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome, and hypertensive encephalopathy
column5: Headache, altered mental status, focal neurologic deficits, seizures; symptoms depend on location and extent of edema
column6: Develops over hours to days; chronic in brain tumors
column7: Cytotoxic edema, tumor progression, hemorrhage, infection
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging shows T2 and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery hyperintensity predominantly in white matter; contrast enhancement indicates blood-brain barrier disruption; computed tomography shows hypodensity
column9: Corticosteroids such as dexamethasone for tumor-related edema; treat underlying cause; osmotic therapy if needed; surgical decompression for mass effect

column2: Lateral medullary stroke with crossed sensory loss, ipsilateral Horner syndrome, ataxia, dysphagia, and vertigo; "Don't pick a PICA (posterior inferior cerebellar artery), a bad SIde"
column3: Ischemic infarction of lateral medulla due to posterior inferior cerebellar artery or vertebral artery occlusion; affects spinothalamic tract, nucleus ambiguus, vestibular nuclei, sympathetic fibers, inferior cerebellar peduncle, and spinal trigeminal nucleus
column4: Most common brainstem stroke syndrome; typically affects middle-aged to older adults; vertebral artery dissection is common cause in younger patients
column5: Ipsilateral: facial pain and temperature loss, Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis), ataxia, dysmetria; Contralateral: body pain and temperature loss; Bilateral: dysphagia, hoarseness, hiccups, vertigo, nystagmus, nausea and vomiting
column6: Acute onset over minutes to hours; symptoms may evolve over 24 to 48 hours
column7: Peripheral vestibulopathy, cerebellar stroke, multiple sclerosis, other brainstem strokes, vertebral artery dissection
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging with diffusion-weighted imaging shows lateral medullary infarction; magnetic resonance angiography or computed tomography angiography to evaluate vertebral and posterior inferior cerebellar artery; consider vessel wall imaging if dissection suspected
column9: Acute: intravenous thrombolysis if within window and no contraindications, mechanical thrombectomy for large vessel occlusion; Secondary prevention: antiplatelet therapy or anticoagulation depending on etiology; Symptomatic: dysphagia management, vestibular rehabilitation

column2: Bilateral weakness in "man-in-a-barrel" pattern after hypotensive episode or cardiac surgery; comma-shaped lesion on imaging
column3: Ischemia at border zones between major arterial territories due to systemic hypoperfusion; most commonly between anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery or middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery territories
column4: Accounts for approximately 5% of all ischemic strokes; more prevalent after cardiac surgery than in general stroke population
column5: Bilateral proximal arm weakness greater than distal or leg weakness; cognitive impairment; visual field defects; symptoms depend on affected watershed zone
column6: Acute onset; symptoms may develop during or shortly after hypotensive event or cardiac procedure
column7: Other ischemic stroke subtypes, seizure, hypoglycemia, posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging with diffusion-weighted imaging shows characteristic border zone infarcts; computed tomography less sensitive; evaluate for cardiac dysfunction, carotid stenosis, hypotension
column9: Restore adequate cerebral perfusion; blood pressure optimization; address underlying cause such as cardiac dysfunction or severe carotid stenosis; antiplatelet therapy; risk factor modification

column2: Ipsilateral third nerve palsy with contralateral hemiparesis; "cerebral peduncle stroke, most common midbrain syndrome"
column3: Ventral midbrain lesion affecting oculomotor nerve fascicles and cerebral peduncle (corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts); most commonly due to posterior cerebral artery branch occlusion; also tuberculoma, lymphoma, aneurysm, toxoplasmosis in immunocompromised
column4: Most common midbrain syndrome; typically affects adults with vascular risk factors; tuberculoma more common in endemic areas; toxoplasmosis in acquired immunodeficiency syndrome patients
column5: Ipsilateral: third nerve palsy (ptosis, mydriasis, eye down and out, impaired adduction, elevation, depression); Contralateral: hemiparesis or hemiplegia affecting face, arm, and leg
column6: Acute onset with stroke (minutes to hours); subacute with mass lesions or infections (days to weeks)
column7: Benedikt syndrome (has tremor and ataxia), Claude syndrome (has ataxia), other midbrain strokes, brain tumor, tuberculoma, toxoplasmosis
column8: Magnetic resonance imaging shows ventral midbrain lesion involving cerebral peduncle; magnetic resonance angiography for vascular assessment; contrast enhancement for mass lesions; human immunodeficiency virus testing and toxoplasma serology if immunocompromised; tuberculosis workup if indicated
column9: Acute stroke: thrombolysis or thrombectomy if eligible; secondary prevention; treat underlying cause: antitubercular therapy and steroids for tuberculoma, antiretroviral therapy and pyrimethamine-sulfadiazine for toxoplasmosis; physical therapy

column2: Malnourished alcoholic patient with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (classic triad); chronic phase with severe anterograde amnesia and confabulation
column3: Thiamine deficiency impairs carbohydrate metabolism and causes selective neuronal damage in mammillary bodies, medial thalamus, periaqueductal gray matter, and pons; alcohol inhibits thiamine absorption and conversion to active forms
column4: Autopsy prevalence 0.4 to 2.8 percent; 80 percent of untreated Wernicke encephalopathy progresses to Korsakoff syndrome; only 16 percent present with complete classic triad; underdiagnosed with only 20 percent recognized clinically
column5: Wernicke encephalopathy: altered mental status (confusion, lethargy, delirium), ocular dysfunction (nystagmus, ophthalmoplegia, restricted eye movements), gait ataxia, hypothermia, hypotension; may include vomiting, weight loss, urinary retention, infections; Korsakoff syndrome: severe anterograde and retrograde amnesia, confabulation, apathy, preserved alertness and working memory
column6: Wernicke encephalopathy: acute onset over days to weeks; symptoms improve within hours to days with thiamine; Korsakoff syndrome: chronic, often permanent sequelae following untreated or inadequately treated Wernicke encephalopathy
column7: Alcohol withdrawal delirium, hepatic encephalopathy, hypoglycemia, stroke, meningitis or encephalitis, other causes of delirium, other nutritional deficiencies, intracranial hemorrhage
column8: Clinical diagnosis using Caine criteria (two of four: dietary deficiency, oculomotor abnormalities, cerebellar dysfunction, altered mental state); magnetic resonance imaging shows symmetric T2 or FLAIR hyperintensities in mammillary bodies, thalamus, periaqueductal gray; whole blood or erythrocyte thiamine levels (not plasma); response to thiamine supports diagnosis
column9: Immediate parenteral thiamine 500 milligrams three times daily for at least 3 to 5 days, then transition to oral thiamine; correct hypomagnesemia if present; multivitamin supplementation; do not delay treatment for diagnostic confirmation; avoid glucose administration before thiamine
